[Collins]: Let's move along to number three.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I mean, it also strikes me, and I apologize for cutting you off, but on the same thread, I think one way to look into this is like, when is the question coming up?

[Collins]: And I know what I often hear is people having a legitimate concern about,

[Collins]: safety when it comes to number of people in a house.

[Collins]: You know, there were those very high profile tragedies like maybe a decade ago at this point about overcrowded housing in student areas.

[Collins]: Obviously, we don't want to, I don't think that these rules are widely abused, but we don't want to create loopholes where people feel there is an invitation to as many people as want can live in this house and people are sleeping in attics.

[Collins]: Obviously, that's not the intent.

[Collins]: But I think like maybe one way of asking this question, it's like, where is this coming up in City Hall?

[Collins]: Like, when is this question coming to us?

[Collins]: And from there, is it the number of occupants that we ought to try to define and then regulate because that regulation is being negotiated or is it the size of the building?

[Collins]: I think that's a really helpful illustration of some of what we're talking around here.

[Collins]: What's on my mind after that kind of example, and I'm trying to think of how to phrase this, because I think it's

[Collins]: It's widely known, I care a lot about tenant protections.

[Collins]: But I'm wondering if there's some parallel between overcrowding not being what we're solving for in zoning and that type, obviously we're trying not to create zoning definitions that invite in bad behavior or things to take advantage of.

[Collins]: But in the same way, I don't want to overcorrect for problems that are also

[Collins]: shouldn't be adjudicated through zoning, but should be adjudicated through a supportive service that City Hall offers, whether it's Board of Health or the Housing Planner or the multilingual support line.

[Collins]: Do you know what I mean?

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Collins]: I think that approach could make sense.

[Collins]: I was thinking along similar lines that it strikes me that some of the concerns that were

[Collins]: talking about here.

[Collins]: And I think just to lay the foundation first, I think it's, I feel pretty comfortable with the current definition as is for the moment while we're contemplating this bigger question, because I think that does still reflect the intent of the council and city staff in allowing people to define for themselves what their household is.

[Collins]: And I do have some, I will admit I have some skepticism about our ability to frame zoning language in a way that helps us get at the enforcement piece of when that is taken advantage of.

[Collins]: I do think it gets into that,

[Collins]: It gets into that issue that we have been talking about mainly with the short-term rentals, where this is more an enforcement issue and building up our capacity to run down those complaints when property owners are doing things with their property that they're not allowed to do, and making sure that tenants or boarders are okay and get the support that they need in those cases where that is happening.

[Collins]: And so I think that in terms of the definition, it makes sense to consider this alongside other more similar

[Collins]: definitions like the boarding house, the dormitory, and I think the rest of it might get into a conversation that's slightly outside of the scope of zoning, or at least blurs outside of the scope of zoning, such as with, of course, the complaints about, the fears about overcrowding of parking on residential streets, and when homes are becoming busier.

[Collins]: I think it's familiar to all of us, and for example, one way the city has been thinking about addressing that is through

[Collins]: mechanisms like zoned parking.

[Collins]: So I think there's some latitude that we have in zoning and there's others that we have through other mechanisms that kind of go alongside it.

[Collins]: Right.

[Collins]: Also worth noting that occasionally individual rooms are rented out, and that's wanted and desired and unproblematic.

[Collins]: older brother was a Medford resident for a long time in a situation like that, so just to state that for the record as well.

[Collins]: I think it makes sense to consider, you know, what's the language that captured, I think that this language captures our current intent comfortably.

[Collins]: And maybe there's a new definition to add to the roster to capture this one.

[Collins]: Any additional comments on

[Collins]: household.

[Collins]: This has been a fruitful conversation, I think.

[Collins]: No?

[Collins]: I'll suggest we move on unless there's any additional comments from Councilors on household.

[Collins]: I think this is to ask an obvious question.

[Collins]: So this is specifically for incorporated nonprofits use of land and lots.

[Collins]: Any comments or questions by Councilors?

[Collins]: And again, this was an existing use that simply did not have a definition previously.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: All right, not seeing any comments from fellow councillors, we can move on.

[Collins]: for me, this one looks good.

[Collins]: I think that this follows with our principle of letting definitions be definitions and not imposing additional standards that might get us into the weeds where it's not helpful.

[Collins]: Initial questions from councillors.

[Collins]: And so just to clarify, I noticed suggested definitions for sort of differentiating manufactured homes versus tiny houses and keeping the current definition for mobile home.

[Collins]: Okay, thank you.

[Collins]: those themes of great substance outlined in the climate action adaptation plan, the housing production plan, after we dispense with this kind of update round.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: Yeah, I appreciate that clarity.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: So this is a motion to support the aforementioned bills that are currently in the State House.

[Collins]: I received outreach about this from several people that work with the Massachusetts Action for Pilot group.

[Collins]: This comprises workers and representatives of various social service and educational, et cetera, workers from across the state, all in support of this legislation, which kind of comes up year after year.

[Collins]: The context for this is that currently in Massachusetts, large nonprofits that meet certain criteria are exempt from property tax.

[Collins]: We have several of those here in Medford, most notably Tufts, my alma mater.

[Collins]: As an alumnus of Tufts, I've always felt my particular responsibility to advocate for changing that rule so that cities such as ours can implement

[Collins]: more fair, essentially compensation systems with these institutions that take up such a large footprint in our communities, but don't have to pay property taxes like everybody else does.

[Collins]: So this bill would enable a local option that communities can choose to adopt.

[Collins]: that would require that these large nonprofit organizations pay really only 25% of the tax obligation that they would otherwise have to submit if they weren't tax exempt.

[Collins]: So it's really, in my opinion, it's not even going as far as it should, but so many of our conversations behind this rail are talking about the various infrastructural projects and personnel and services

[Collins]: that we ought to be able to provide to our residents that we can't because of a lack of funds.

[Collins]: So any action that this council can take to level the playing field, I think is a worthwhile one.

[Collins]: And I ask my fellow Councilors for their consideration in lobbying the state house to allow us to give us one more leverage when we're looking for fair compensation from these large, well-endowed institutions that we host in our community.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: President Bears a motion to suspend the rules and take two four zero nine two at order on the motion to spend the rules.

[Collins]: Through the chair to Councilor Scarpelli, I hope you know that I sincerely respect you very much.

[Collins]: I've always enjoyed working with you, and I respect you enough to want to correct the record when things are being said that I think are a bad faith attack on my character.

[Collins]: I think that anybody who's willing to engage in this in good faith knows that there is a difference between me

[Collins]: as an individual, using my name and my title to speak as an individual, using my petition, signing a letter in support of something, being crystal clear, it's me as an individual endorsing something.

[Collins]: I do that all of the time, on many platforms, on letters, on social media, and individual phone calls with various administrations saying I'm speaking as myself.

[Collins]: Every councillor here

[Collins]: Every Councilor here has the opportunity to do that.

[Collins]: Some exercise it more than others.

[Collins]: Everybody in any role has an opportunity to say that, to say, this is the experience that I'm speaking from.

[Collins]: I'm not speaking for my constituency, necessarily, when I'm signing a letter saying, I endorse this as a public official.

[Collins]: This is concurrent with our public process.

[Collins]: We are going to have publicly noticed committee meetings about the real estate transfer fee.

[Collins]: At the same time, just like everybody here, I retain the right to say, I as an individual endorse that process.

[Collins]: I also want to bring up, well, there's a lot to say about this.

[Collins]: I think it's really regrettable that there has been so much consternation about, you know, this is a polarizing issue, and I get that.

[Collins]: And maybe that's not even worth regretting, because polarizing issues are always going to be polarizing.

[Collins]: And it's how we move on from that that's really important.

[Collins]: I really take umbrage with the assertion that having some people in office who are supportive of one thing and other people also in office and also out of office who don't agree and going through that process of friction and tension and talking about it and arguing about it in public session

[Collins]: I disagree that that's harmful.

[Collins]: And I take umbrage with the fact that being in support of something that doesn't have consensus is harming this community.

[Collins]: We are going to talk about this in public session, as we have been doing, until it gets to the time we're going to put it to a vote.

[Collins]: And when we put it to a vote, I want to remind everybody, what we put to a vote is simply asking the state for the authority to again meet in public session to deliberate on what we should do as a community.

[Collins]: I don't believe that perception is reality, actually.

[Collins]: And I think that when people are telling us how something should make us feel, we should follow the money.

[Collins]: And I hope that, I know we're gonna continue to talk about these issues in committee, these polarizing issues, these issues that leave many of us feeling extremely passionate.

[Collins]: but I think we should all come with our own opinions and a mutual respect and an unwillingness to believe that anybody in the room is out to get the other person.

[Collins]: And whoever's telling you that somebody in the room is out to get the other person, they're probably wrong, because we all live here.

[Collins]: Thanks.

[Collins]: Wait, can I interject really quickly?

[Collins]: No, Councilor Scarpelli, I didn't mean that you were being deceitful.

[Collins]: Yeah, well, I can read the full text.

[Collins]: We should go to public participation or call to question.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears and Gaston.

[Collins]: I'm sorry to interrupt you.

[Collins]: I do think I was just gonna

[Collins]: I think that's more relevant to a resolution that is coming up.

[Collins]: So, sorry.

[Collins]: Yeah, I'm happy to.

[Collins]: Thank you for indulging me.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I apologize.

[Collins]: I made a motion to call the question, but I just want to interject with one more thing.

[Collins]: Like I mentioned, I exercise my right and privilege to add my name to sign on letters at my discretion.

[Collins]: Another topic that we talked about earlier in the agenda, the payment in lieu of tax legislation that's being considered by the State House.

[Collins]: Last week, I also added my name to a list of signatories separate from the paper that we discussed and dispensed with tonight, I also signed that letter.

[Collins]: acting as myself as an individual, signing on as Kit Collins, Vice President of the Medford City Council.

[Collins]: And like all the other times that I've done that, the letter was not phrased in such a way as to purport that I was speaking for this council, because I wasn't.

[Collins]: I made no assertion of speaking for this council, because I wasn't.

[Collins]: I was endorsing it as an individual.

[Collins]: Tonight, when we passed that resolution, we chose, through our votes, to endorse it as a council.

[Collins]: And I don't disparage anybody for feeling angry or disappointed in me for choosing to advocate for issues that you would rather I not.

[Collins]: That is your right.

[Collins]: I know that there are many people in the community who disagree with me on that issue and many others, and many who do.

[Collins]: And that is your right, and it is absolutely your right and your privilege to say so in these public meetings, however you want to.

[Collins]: However, I really do think that we need to correct the record and draw a distinction between an individual official endorsing a policy using their own individual name and saying that this is in some way a breach of our process.

[Collins]: They are two separate things.

[Collins]: You are well within your rights to say, I disagree with you and I wish you wouldn't advocate for that, but that's not the same thing as us breaking a regulation.

[Collins]: And I really will stop speaking on the topic now.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Barras.

[Collins]: Thank you for speaking to this.

[Collins]: And again, this is similar to what I said before, but I again want to reinforce, I know that you disagree with, I'm sorry, through the chair, I know that many constituents disagree with me about my opinion on the transfer fee, the Home Rule petition, the Affordable Homes Act, which are again, two separate, totally separate processes about the same topic.

[Collins]: That's your right, completely respect that.

[Collins]: I know that there's a lot that we disagree on and a lot that we agree on.

[Collins]: But the thing that I really think is important to reinforce

[Collins]: is that we are talking about two different things.

[Collins]: We are all endowed with the right to endorse a piece of state-level legislation.

[Collins]: I think we've probably all done that at different times.

[Collins]: And there's a separate process.

[Collins]: Or oppose.

[Collins]: Or oppose.

[Collins]: And there is a separate process by which we come together as a city council in committee meetings to collectively, in public session, craft what we are actually putting forward to the state house to say,

[Collins]: the majority of city councilors voted for this, that we would like for you to put forward as state legislation.

[Collins]: And I hope that, I'm trying to find the words to make this more clear, because I understand that it's confusing for a lot of people, that the Affordable Homes Act, which is a massive housing bond bill that also includes a proposal for a local option for real estate transfer fee, encounters the same topic as our proposed real estate

[Collins]: transfer fee home rule petition that is currently in the permitting and planning committee.

[Collins]: I understand that those are easy to conflate because there's that Venn diagram overlap.

[Collins]: And I just want to reinforce for people who are not as deeply intimate with this issue as all of us behind the rail are and the people who most frequently show up to the public meetings, I just want to make it crystal clear that these are two separate processes.

[Collins]: They're related by topic.

[Collins]: They're two separate processes, and I just think that's really important to make clear.

[Collins]: And if I may, while I have the floor, as we're talking about the processes with possible home rule petitions, I think the most important part of this conversation already happened, which is how do these actually happen?

[Collins]: What's the process?

[Collins]: City Council goes to the mayor.

[Collins]: They could full stop at the mayor.

[Collins]: If they don't, they go to the delegation.

[Collins]: They get put forward as a legislation.

[Collins]: I don't like to talk about this often because I think that we should do them anyway, but yeah, I have no optimism that the Home Rule petition that we may or may not craft here in Medford City Council will become law because traditionally they don't.

[Collins]: I've been a member of home, I've been a participant in home rule petition efforts in my first term on the Medford City Council.

[Collins]: Did any of them become law or get even close?

[Collins]: No, absolutely not.

[Collins]: But, you know, to use the words of somebody who spoke just earlier, I don't think that this is a slight issue at all, the housing crisis.

[Collins]: I think that it's a major issue.

[Collins]: And that's why I think that's it.

[Collins]: That's why I think it's so important that we have the conversation with every mechanism possible, including lobbying for state-level legislation, as well as having the conversation about if we should lobby for this, essentially, with a home rule petition, because the issue of displacement and housing unaffordability is so large and so rampant in Medford that I really think it's worth having that conversation anyway.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears and Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: I appreciate you refocusing us on the actual text of our discussion.

[Collins]: So I just want to make one further comment, and then I will

[Collins]: the question again, I guess, though I feel more confused about the meaning of that motion than I did a half hour ago.

[Collins]: But in terms of the, I think, the most important part of our discussion about the processes of dealing with possible home rule petitions is just the technical process, like the universe of what can happen with home rule petitions, which we already talked about.

[Collins]: Most of politics is just disagreeing over the tactics and not the outcomes or goals.

[Collins]: And to that end, my expectation as chair of the committee in which a lot of these affordable housing conversations are going on is that we have, this is also the committee in which we are discussing our slate of major comprehensive amendments to our zoning code.

[Collins]: And that gets brought up a lot.

[Collins]: People talk about making it easier for developers to build in Medford

[Collins]: both to increase our commercial tax base, to make it easier to add new high quality residential units.

[Collins]: I think we're so serious about the issue of housing affordability that when we say every tool in the toolbox, we really mean it.

[Collins]: We're going to talk about zoning that will make it easier to develop commercially and residentially in Medford.

[Collins]: We're going to talk about ADUs, which I know are really important, you know, kind of on the minds of many Medford residents.

[Collins]: Along with President Bears, I've also been made aware of the situation by protesters on Tufts campus and people working with them, supportive of their cause.

[Collins]: I've been very clear with all of those leaders and decision makers that my opinion is that

[Collins]: This is, it would be a insupportable use of city resources to deploy Medford police to break up what has been a peaceful and unproblematic student demonstration.

[Collins]: This is not germane to the use of our city resources, but as a Tufts alumnus, I'm very proud to see the students there joining into this cascade of peaceful demonstrations across the nation.

[Collins]: And speaking as a community representative, I am deeply concerned about the safety of students and other community members on campus should the Tufts administration decide that a forcible removal of protesters is the objective that they are going to accomplish by use of force and by use of Tufts University Police.

[Collins]: I hope that it doesn't come to that.

[Collins]: I pray that it doesn't come to that.

[Collins]: I think that that would end badly.

[Collins]: I think that we've seen on other campuses that this is an extenuating event that should be allowed to remain a peaceful demonstration, a gathering place, a place for students and community members to process what's going on, to gather together and to show their solidarity.

[Collins]: I think that it would be, I would hate to see something so benign

[Collins]: speaking here as an individual community member, and again, speaking as a Jewish person, I would hate to see something so benign be escalated because of the use of police force in breaking up a peaceful protest.

[Collins]: And so I'll reiterate my message to our administration and Tufts administration that I unequivocally would condemn the use of police force, whether Tufts or Medfords, especially Medfords, to forcibly decamp the protesters

[Collins]: from where they have been camping out, gathering, making food, celebrating Passover on the Tufts University academic quad.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Sorry, just one thing to add.

[Collins]: I know a couple people have reached out to me saying, what can the city council do about this to make sure that the people demonstrating on Tufts campus are kept safe?

[Collins]: As we often say, the city council instructs and commands no city staff.

[Collins]: There's very little that we can, there's nothing that we can do to interfere formally, or sorry, I shouldn't say interfere.

[Collins]: There's nothing that we can do directly.

[Collins]: to affect what happens on Tufts campus, but I would say to constituents that are observing this meeting, if you are of the opinion one way or the other on how Medford police resources should be deployed, if you feel that they should not be used to disperse a peaceful encampment on the grounds of a private university, if you feel that's inappropriate, now would be a good time to let the administration know.

[Collins]: I just wanted to, before I leave you to your deliberations, I think that this is a really great start, a really great framework.

[Collins]: I'm excited about this.

[Collins]: I think what I hear from people all the time, like in my first term as well as recently, is it's so hard to know what the city council is doing.

[Collins]: And this is of course not a perfect solution, but I think anything that we add

[Collins]: And the beauty of essentially an e-list is that people can always be added to it, and that content can be used in other channels as well.

[Collins]: So I think that this is a worthwhile endeavor that is only additive.

[Collins]: It doesn't really take away from anything except for our time.

[Collins]: I think that in general, it could be helpful for us to just have standard language for how we talk about certain things.

[Collins]: In my email that I sent over to you earlier today, just kind of a standard sentence structure for at our XYZ meeting, we passed a resolution commemorating

[Collins]: I just want to run through these really quickly.

[Collins]: A lot of my comments did just kind of trying to get into the trying to get into the mindset of the average resident who doesn't know what we do.

[Collins]: So one of the comments that I sent to you, um.

[Collins]: Around the passage of the leaf blower ordinance.

[Collins]: I suggested

[Collins]: as opposed to we approved completely the new leaf blower ordinance, sending it to the mayor for the final approval.

[Collins]: This ordinance will phase out gas-powered leaf blowers in favor of electric ones over a four-year period.

[Collins]: And I just want to emphasize, I think it's helpful to not assume that people know what it means to pass an ordinance completely or incompletely, just to sort of use kind of specific language for what we mean by that, to kind of imply that there's two votes, rather than to use general language.

[Collins]: And a lot of our ordinances are, of course, are very complicated.

[Collins]: They're hard to boil down into one or two sentences.

[Collins]: So I think that

[Collins]: I think it'd be great for us to include hyperlinks wherever we can so that, you know, to sort of help people with their inevitable questions of what do you mean, what do you mean specifically, where can I read more about this, so that people can click to immediately get their specific questions answered to read more about it.

[Collins]: But wherever possible, I would love to use language like giving the final vote of approval so that it's more clear what we mean by that.

[Collins]: Similarly, in the planning and permitting committee section,

[Collins]: I've been trying to use language of this committee began the process of updating and amending our zoning ordinances.

[Collins]: I just think that's a little bit more specific than I know I've been using the word overhaul a lot.

[Collins]: I think that it's like a little more precise when we say we're amending the ordinances.

[Collins]: We're updating the ordinances.

[Collins]: I hope that that will

[Collins]: better signal for more people what that process actually looks like.

[Collins]: And then I do think it might be helpful for people to include that second line that I suggested.

[Collins]: NS Associates has worked with the city of Medford previously, including on our comprehensive plan, just to give that context that this is a known contractor that we've collaborated with before.

[Collins]: Um, and last thing, sorry, um, if this hasn't already been mentioned, um, under the administration finance committee section, I thought it would be helpful to add some context to the draft budget ordinance.

[Collins]: I suggested, and this I emailed to you earlier, this committee is finalizing the draft budget ordinance, which for the first time creates a timeline and meeting schedules for updates and communications between the city council and mayor's office during the annual budget development.

[Collins]: process, and I just wanted to include some sort of implication there that we're at the final stage of this, something that was begun in the previous term, and more specifically what that means.

[Collins]: What I was just referencing was the email that I sent to you before.

[Collins]: Okay.

[Collins]: So I did, so I did, I did include everything in that in the meantime, but you also sent, um, I was just noticing some language discrepancies from what I sent you and what I saw on the doc.

[Collins]: So I just wanted to make sure that you have the specific language.

[Collins]: bring the two numbers in reconciliation with each other.

[Collins]: 24082 resolution to acknowledge April 30, 2024 as National Animal Therapy Day in the city of Medford.

[Collins]: Whereas there are thousands of pet partners therapy animal teams serving communities across the United States.

[Collins]: And whereas pet partners has designated April 30 as National Therapy Animal Day.

[Collins]: And whereas scientific research shows that interacting with therapy animals can reduce stress, relieve depression, slow the heart rate, lower blood pressure and strengthen the immune system.

[Collins]: And whereas therapy animal teams in the city of Medford play an essential role in improving human health and well-being through the human animal bond.

[Collins]: And whereas therapy animal teams interact with a variety of people in our community, including veterans, seniors, patients, students, and those approaching end of life.

[Collins]: And whereas these exceptional therapy animals who partner with their human companions bring comfort and healing to those in need.

[Collins]: And whereas we encourage more pet owners to consider becoming pet partners, volunteers,

[Collins]: to help our community by creating greater access to meaningful therapy animal visits.

[Collins]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we acknowledge April 30th, 2024 as National Animal Therapy Day and encourage our citizens to celebrate our therapy animals and their human handlers.

[Collins]: Be it further resolved that we publicly salute the service of therapy animal teams in our community and in communities across the nation.

[Collins]: be it further resolved that we request that Mayor Lungo-Koehn issue a formal proclamation of National Animal Therapy Day in the city of Medford.

[Collins]: This is a comment, not a motion, but I just wanted to reflect that I think this

[Collins]: stage of the process kind of encapsulates a lot of what we're trying to do here which is both taking the visions and goals of the plans that we've the city is, you know, collaboratively created over the past three to five years, and putting those into a zoning code where they can actually be implemented and residents can start to see changes like the type they've been requesting for.

[Collins]: you know, in some cases, decades, depending on the topic at hand.

[Collins]: And at the same time, it's also a process that is meant to streamline how, you know, the work of the city gets done and how development gets done and make this a city where the type of development that we do want to be happening can happen more efficiently, more easily with less burden on city staff and also the people that are trying to build and work and contribute to our community.

[Collins]: you know, both facets of many represented in this meeting.

[Collins]: At this meeting of the Planning and Permitting Committee, we discussed two resolutions, one from the previous term about amending the short-term rental ordinance.

[Collins]: to include a monthly report from the short-term rental platforms such as Vrbo or Airbnb so that we can better reconcile the post-reported and platform-reported number of short-term rentals in the community and make sure that we're in compliance with the short-term rental ordinance.

[Collins]: We also discussed a resolution from this term to review the fee schedule for like across city departments and boards to make sure that

[Collins]: we go through the process of asking city departments for feedback on which of those fees are updated or out of step with our neighboring communities so that we can make sure those fees are covering the relevant administrative costs and brought into the modern age.

[Collins]: Motion for approval.

[Collins]: I'll defer to that.

[Collins]: I'll second your motion.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: As I said last week in committee, I appreciate Councilor Leming for bringing this forward.

[Collins]: I think that even if all we were doing was updating the technical aspects of this ordinance that are out of step with how it's actually utilized, that would be a productive thing to do.

[Collins]: And I think it's in keeping with where we're at as a community and this modern moment.

[Collins]: to be adding, as we discussed at length last week, the point of the linkage fees is to associate certain costs from developers for the things that they affect in our community when they come in and build here.

[Collins]: Things like parks, things like roads, sewer.

[Collins]: I think it's appropriate to be adding an affordable housing bucket at this time.

[Collins]: And I look forward to reviewing the recommendations that the city board comes back to us with.

[Collins]: So I'd motion to refer to the community development board

[Collins]: Council.

[Collins]: 24059 offered by Councilor Callahan resolution to create a rental registry.

[Collins]: Whereas the city of Medford has climate sustainability, affordable housing and other goals that would be easier to accomplish if we could reach either renters or landlords or both in our city, and whereas a lack of a registry of rental properties means that we currently miss opportunities to reach either our renters or our landlords or both.

[Collins]: Be it so

[Collins]: with energy efficiency standards as described in the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan, Section 2.2.D.

[Collins]: Be it further resolved that this ordinance be referred to committee for further discussion in the Planning and Permitting Committee.

[Collins]: Be it further resolved that members of the Planning and Permitting Committee submit questions to the chair, clerk, and city staff ahead of the committee meeting scheduled for the subject.

[Collins]: and be it further resolved that the council work with the building department and the Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability on the drafting of this ordinance to ensure that it best serves the city of Medford and our climate and affordable housing goals.

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: We're gonna go to President Bears, Councilor Leming, and then Councilor Tseng.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Councilor Leming.

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan, if you have a direct response.

[Collins]: Councilor Tseng and then Councilor Scarpelli.

[Collins]: you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Excuse me, we're not going to interrupt people.

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan, please go ahead.

[Collins]: There will be a chance for everybody to participate on this item.

[Collins]: Please do not interrupt speakers.

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan, are you finished?

[Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you for letting me know.

[Collins]: I appreciate the discussion from my fellow Councilors.

[Collins]: I appreciate everybody who's come to the podium to speak on this.

[Collins]: I am aware that hearing people tonight, people feel like they're not being heard.

[Collins]: I'm also aware that there's probably not a lot that I can say that people believe, such as when I say that everything that people have spoken to, I'm listening to.

[Collins]: I won't speak for my fellow Councilors, but I know it's true for them as well.

[Collins]: We're listening.

[Collins]: I'm taking notes.

[Collins]: We hear you.

[Collins]: I'll echo what Councilor Callahan said.

[Collins]: I think that engaging in every part of this process is important, taking note of things that really concern people with this proposal.

[Collins]: For example, people are wondering, does this include compromising information?

[Collins]: I don't think it does, but I think that's something for us to talk about in committee and make crystal clear.

[Collins]: People are saying, why is this necessary when I know that you have info about property owners already?

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I think that's...

[Collins]: I think that's a great question and we should look at okay, what really needs to be added to augment already already have, I think the most salient thing for me, all the folks in this room that are property owners.

[Collins]: I think Councilor Callahan made it really clear at the beginning, that's not who we're talking about.

[Collins]: people said, we know that there are property owners in this community that are hurting neighbors as well as tenants.

[Collins]: They're not the folks who are here talking about how much work they're putting into their properties.

[Collins]: Those are the folks that we can't reach.

[Collins]: And those are the folks that we need to be able to reach that we make sure that they are contributing to the community the way that all of you are.

[Collins]: I think this is, I know we're coming up on my time limit.

[Collins]: That's why I think this is worth considering further so that we can get into the concerns that were raised tonight.

[Collins]: and elucidate them and get that clarity and have those discussions with everybody who we already know is interested in this conversation and all the people that we didn't hear from tonight, because those perspectives need to be- Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I appreciate my fellow Councilors for bringing this forward.

[Collins]: I also appreciate the motion on the floor to amend it from two minutes to three minutes.

[Collins]: I think that's welcome change.

[Collins]: Two minutes feels a bit too much of a cut right off the bat.

[Collins]: I think three minutes is more reasonable.

[Collins]: I think that for myself is supportable.

[Collins]: My reasons are the following.

[Collins]: I think that this is a tweak that will

[Collins]: help more people to participate in our meetings.

[Collins]: I can hear the response in my head and also slightly from the chambers of another way of looking at this, which is, you know, gosh, those jerks are really tired of long meetings.

[Collins]: We know the job that we signed up for.

[Collins]: Sorry, I'll speak for myself.

[Collins]: I know the job that I signed up for.

[Collins]: We have a lot of long nights.

[Collins]: I know how to prep for it.

[Collins]: I drink coffee in the afternoon.

[Collins]: I eat before the meetings.

[Collins]: I'm paid to listen to you.

[Collins]: I'm gonna do that if we have to be here till 1 a.m.

[Collins]: every night.

[Collins]: That's the job, committed to it.

[Collins]: What I think is not okay is we're experiencing a tension between wanting to optimize for the number for people being able to speak at the length that they choose and wanting to make it possible for more people to speak at all.

[Collins]: And I think for a lot of meetings in a row, we've experienced people not being able to say their piece, people showing up and tending to speak and having to leave early because they have to get up for work.

[Collins]: They have to go put their child to bed.

[Collins]: any other reason, they can't stay up until midnight with us all.

[Collins]: I just saw it happen.

[Collins]: I know there are some folks here to speak on a later resolution who said, I could speak if it comes up before 9.30, it's 9.40, they can't be heard.

[Collins]: And I think that that is, I think that that leaves people out of the process.

[Collins]: I think that this is a way that we can make a small tweak to finesse this one avenue for participation that could have the result of allowing more people to participate.

[Collins]: concurrently, I think that we can always do a better job of publicizing the various ways, other ways that residents can let their feelings be known with Councilors, which as Councilor Tseng noted, we still have the public participation section at the end of every agenda.

[Collins]: Our information is public on the city website all the time, and I'm always really grateful to people who make use of that and always encourage more people to do so.

[Collins]: People can submit comments to the president, to the city clerk to have them entered into the minutes or to be read aloud into the record.

[Collins]: I also do want to note that like all of our other rules that are governing this body, this is enforced at the discretion of the chair, whoever that may be, which gives us the option to make exceptions where the need arises or where the space arises.

[Collins]: For example, when we have a short agenda and aren't under time pressures, we can give everybody a little bit more breathing room in the event of, you know, I've heard from other communities, you know,

[Collins]: using that discretion to allow more time for people with speech disabilities who do need more time to say their piece.

[Collins]: And I think this gives us a tool to allow more people to come to the podium, if that's the avenue that they want to share their feelings with the council, while still giving us the flexibility and doubling down on our other ways for having residents communicate with the council.

[Collins]: So I'll support the motion to move this forward tonight.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Any further comment from councilors?

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I'll try to keep this brief, but I think that we are touching on what seems to me to be an important topic kind of underwriting this council right now.

[Collins]: I think that

[Collins]: You know, as we have stated tonight and many other times, we're doing things a little bit differently this term.

[Collins]: We have more in different committees where meeting in committee is way more often.

[Collins]: We put out a governing agenda, which we'll continue to revise and update, which we've never done before.

[Collins]: The council is going through growing pains.

[Collins]: I think the committee is, the community is going through growing pains and seeing our evolution as a council and our workflow and trying to get used to that and trying to participate and understand, you know,

[Collins]: what that looks like and how to plug into it.

[Collins]: And I just want to acknowledge that as a thing that I think is going on and that it makes sense to be going on.

[Collins]: I think that this is an important topic because I think that a lot of what people are wanting, we are trying to do.

[Collins]: And I know that there's some breakdowns in trust because I think that there's some

[Collins]: messaging about what we're here to do, that is unfair and untrue, but has legs.

[Collins]: And I think, I hope we're going to work through that.

[Collins]: I think that that makes it hard to communicate when we say, you know, I hear folks say, you know, we feel like we should be a part of the process and we're not a part of the process.

[Collins]: I think that this council is trying to, for example,

[Collins]: make committees a place where people really do come together and get into the weeds with us.

[Collins]: Historically, they haven't been that.

[Collins]: The fellow Councilors are right.

[Collins]: Usually attendance is super low.

[Collins]: I think we all really want to change that.

[Collins]: Are we there right now?

[Collins]: No, absolutely not.

[Collins]: Does it need to get better?

[Collins]: Absolutely.

[Collins]: I really appreciate people calling that out and also making suggestions to say,

[Collins]: you know, here's how we need to do this differently so that the energy and the input that we get at these meetings, what can we do differently and what just needs time so that that energy and that level of input is occurring in the place where it is on the schedule for us to get into the weeds together.

[Collins]: I think we have some co-evolving to do to get to that place.

[Collins]: And I hope that we'll get there.

[Collins]: And for myself as one Councilor for this group, I think that's an honest effort in good faith and to anybody from the community who is willing to bring that energy and that frustration and that irritation to help us get there, that's welcome.

[Collins]: And just as an illustrative example, because for me as one Councilor, it is frustrating to hear people say, we know this is a done deal or see what is sometimes a consensus and call it a conspiracy

[Collins]: I think it's fairly intuitive that people running, committing to do similar things, similar people voted for similar ideas.

[Collins]: And so now there's plurality of that opinion on the council.

[Collins]: I don't think that's a conspiracy.

[Collins]: I think that's statistics.

[Collins]: So it's frustrating to me to hear, this is a done deal, this is something shady, for an example of, I think what we're trying to, I wish that we got more,

[Collins]: attention all the times when we're stuck in the weeds.

[Collins]: Council President Bears mentioned earlier at the very beginning of the meeting 10 years ago, the report on the food trucks ordinance.

[Collins]: Where is it?

[Collins]: So thank you for indulging me.

[Collins]: You have no right.

[Collins]: No, no, I think we should just move on.

[Collins]: We'll go to Councilor Shang and then Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Any further comment from councilors on the B paper?

[Collins]: Hearing none, I will relinquish the chair.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I appreciate you reading out the full text of the resolution.

[Collins]: I am really proud to have put this on the agenda today.

[Collins]: The reason that this resolution is before us is because we have a really strong, robust, energetic climate and environment community here in Medford.

[Collins]: A couple of those groups have formed a coalition that came to me with the idea for this resolution, which is one of advocacy to say, we as a community,

[Collins]: We see how climate change is already affecting our community.

[Collins]: We see how it is going to affect our community in the future.

[Collins]: We look around, we see reality for what it is.

[Collins]: We know that we need resources greater than we can muster in a city's operating budget to adequately contend with how climate change is going to affect our community here on the banks of the Mystic River in a way that will protect residents of all backgrounds who live in all neighborhoods,

[Collins]: of all the various geographies of Medford in a way that we can all continue to enjoy quality of life and safety here in Medford, both right now and a year in 50 years because of what we know about how our local environment is going to change because of the global weather trends that we are all experiencing and all projecting in different ways.

[Collins]: This is a bill that was proposed this legislative session.

[Collins]: And again, to sort of reiterate what was stated in the text of the resolution, this is a bill that would enable the state of Massachusetts to create a fund that the largest corporate polluters would pay into, that money would then be earmarked for local climate change resiliency projects.

[Collins]: for cities like ours, who are on the banks of rivers, who are already suffering from heat islands, extreme weather, so that we can do the work that we already know we need to do, that people already need and actually don't have the access that they need quite already in our community, so that we can do those projects adequately.

[Collins]: I don't think that eight-hour heating and cooling centers in the coldest and hottest days of the month in Medford are cutting it already, let alone what we're going to be feeling

[Collins]: in five or 10 or 20 years.

[Collins]: This state level legislation would try to create a stream of money to combat that at the local level in communities like ours from the corporations that are responsible for creating these conditions in communities like ours.

[Collins]: So to be super, super clear, this is a tax on no consumer.

[Collins]: This is a tax on no resident.

[Collins]: This is going to your Exxon mobiles and saying,

[Collins]: We can't undo history, but now you have to help us.

[Collins]: You have to help us stay alive.

[Collins]: You have to help us stay safe.

[Collins]: You have to help us preserve our communities with what we know is to come.

[Collins]: As was noted in the text of the resolution, this was given a study order in this legislative session, which means that most likely the legislature will not take action on this section.

[Collins]: They won't be able to.

[Collins]: They've decided to consider it for the rest of the year instead, which means slower action.

[Collins]: And this is, you know, in some cases, this is a way of taking the wind out of the sails of a legislative project or slowing the momentum.

[Collins]: But I think that this presents, you know, a really urgent opportunity for communities like ours to step in and say, you know, it's all the more important to be advocating because we know the clock is ticking.

[Collins]: It was ticking before, it's certainly ticking now that the legislature has declined to take action on it in this session.

[Collins]: And I'm really proud to stand with many Medford residents who reached out to me to say, we can't afford to add any more years to this timeline.

[Collins]: We need to start funding climate resiliency now.

[Collins]: So I'd like to thank the coalition that brought this before me and thank my Councilors as I asked them for their support.

[Collins]: Thank you so much for being here, especially for waiting such a long time.

[Collins]: And it's really helpful to hear it straight from MTA representatives, people who work in the schools like yourself.

[Collins]: So just thank you as always for being here, especially when it takes a really long time to take a turn.

[Collins]: Just wanna echo a lot of what my fellow Councilors have said, and also just, you know, acknowledge, like I know it's been, I know it's always hard.

[Collins]: I know it's been an especially alarming couple of weeks with numbers coming out and then quickly saying,

[Collins]: Sorry, there was an error.

[Collins]: This is the number now, because that affects your day-to-day.

[Collins]: So I just want to acknowledge that.

[Collins]: My fellow Councilors have spoken to our role in this process, which I know for folks pretty intimately familiar with the budget process, is already familiar.

[Collins]: It is tough being so invested in the outcome in the school department budget specifically and having such an abstract role in the budget process at the same time.

[Collins]: I think it really is important to state for the record that while I think, speaking only for myself, we never have as direct of a hand as we want to have in the school department budget or really any city department's budget.

[Collins]: I think it's important to state for the record what

[Collins]: we are trying to do within our city council jurisdiction year round and indeed over the past term into this term to try to lay the conditions where we can get away from this model where around every time this year, it's a scary time and it's an uncertain time and everybody is feeling concern or just feeling disappointment that we're not able to guarantee the things that we all know should be guaranteed.

[Collins]: Really recently on the council side, we approved another PDD

[Collins]: we're already doing on the zoning side to bring up that baseline in terms of our permitting, in terms of our commercial tax base.

[Collins]: One of the three major projects that we're gonna be working on the city council this term is that total zoning reevaluation overhaul.

[Collins]: I feel like I bring this up all the time, but that undergirds everything that we can directly do to get to a city budget where we can reliably fund the things that students deserve, families deserve, teachers deserve,

[Collins]: This is stuff that we have been working on as a council for advocating for that, fighting for that, for longer than I have been on the council.

[Collins]: Now we're at a stage where we are going to start actually making the literal amendments that will allow us to do what we can within our jurisdiction to increase that pie.

[Collins]: And that's not to say that things are the way that they are and that's okay.

[Collins]: They're not okay.

[Collins]: And I think I've made it really clear that I think it's not okay.

[Collins]: Nobody thinks that it's okay.

[Collins]: I am also, I think that it is our responsibility to do everything we can with what's currently on the table to get the best outcomes this year and next year with the tools that we have.

[Collins]: That's why I voted for the budget last year after negotiating procedural improvements that would allow us to, this year, hit the ground running with the financial task force that we did announce last June so that we can have these conversations about

[Collins]: stability measures for how we're going to get away from this kind of crisis model of budgeting.

[Collins]: It's why I'll never hold potential funding opportunities hostage to administration change, because I think that our students deserve more than that, and our teachers deserve more than that, and I think that all of the budgeting improvements that we need to see are already so overdue, and I think that every single person agrees with that, but

[Collins]: we just have to do everything that we can at every single opportunity.

[Collins]: And that's how we have to approach this year.

[Collins]: And I really appreciate everybody from the MTA bringing their perspective to the city council and to the school committee, which of course is always able to answer these questions probably in more granular detail, though I think President Pierce does a great job for a non-school committee member.

[Collins]: And I think that it's up to this council to, in these meetings, talk the talk,

[Collins]: and hold our administration to account, like we said, level service.

[Collins]: That's got to be the floor every year that we have to improve from there.

[Collins]: And then we have to walk the walk in terms of doing what's within our power to increase the pie.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: 24061 resolution to oppose landfill that endangers MWRA water supply.

[Collins]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we join with neighboring communities, environmental protection activists, and the residents of Hardwick MA in opposing the proposed construction of a landfill by Casella Corporation near the Quabbin Reservoir watershed due to the incredible danger it poses to our regional water supply.

[Collins]: Be it further resolved

[Collins]: that a copy of this resolution be forwarded to the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority leadership and the Medford State Legislative Delegation.

[Collins]: This is proposed by President Bears in the previous council term.

[Collins]: It is a resolution to amend short-term rental ordinance to include a monthly report from short-term rental platforms.

[Collins]: And by that, we're talking about platforms such as Airbnb.

[Collins]: The second action item for tonight is paper 24-008, also offered by President Bears.

[Collins]: That is a resolution to review the fee schedule

[Collins]: I will read out the description of each resolution, then I will pass it over to President Bears to further describe these projects.

[Collins]: 23427, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the former Zoning Planning and Development Subcommittee need to discuss amendments to Section 8.4 of the Zoning Ordinance regarding short-term rentals to require a monthly report from all short-term rental platforms

[Collins]: to ensure that short-term rental units in Medford meet all requirements of this section.

[Collins]: And then resolution 24-008, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the fee schedule of the city of Medford, appendix A to the city ordinances be reviewed and updated.

[Collins]: I will now pass it off to President Bears as soon as he is ready to further orient us to these two topics.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears, I appreciate that overview, and I, as one Councilor, certainly I've been at meetings where the nuisance issue that occasionally comes up with short-term rentals has been discussed, and others in which, you know, the effect of taking rentals off of the housing market to turn them into, you know, for example, Airbnb units, or HomeAway units, or Burbo units,

[Collins]: We feel that effect in the availability of rentals citywide.

[Collins]: So I think that this makes sense as part of our overall efforts to keep tabs on activity of the short-term rental platforms in Medford and making sure that at least we have an accurate picture of what's going on.

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Any further comments or questions from Councilors?

[Collins]: I think in that case, we can proceed along to if you have any next steps in mind or care to share that sample language from the city of Boston.

[Collins]: President Bears, whenever you're ready, I think it makes sense to look at the language that other communities have used to mandate that platforms are reporting to the city on how many units they have in operation.

[Collins]: Certainly.

[Collins]: And if I'm happy to screen share if you want to send me a link or if you'd like to do so, whatever is easier.

[Collins]: I will share with you.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bearson.

[Collins]: Just to sort of paraphrase that back to you, the fellow Councilors and residents, this is essentially mandating a report from the short-term booking platform.

[Collins]: that tells the city, you know, we have listings, we have rooms and buildings available within the city of Medford, this is where they are, this is if it's a room or a whole building or a whole unit, and this is the number of nights that each of the units was reported by the renter as being rented to somebody during the month to help us get a picture.

[Collins]: I see this as helping us reconcile

[Collins]: We're hearing from some of the people that rent rooms on the short-term booking platforms.

[Collins]: Yes, this unit is a rental and I rented it for this number of nights.

[Collins]: Reports such as this would capture from the platform side, this is the overall number of units that we know on the back end was rented in the city during this month.

[Collins]: We could see if there's a discrepancy.

[Collins]: Any other comments from councilors at this time, having looked at this draft language?

[Collins]: This would be an amendment to the zoning ordinance.

[Collins]: Hearing none, President Perez, I want to kick it back to you for next steps, if you had any before I share my thoughts.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Actually, let me...

[Collins]: Are there any further comments or questions from councilors or members of the public before we take a vote on the motion?

[Collins]: Yes.

[Collins]: Five in favor, none against.

[Collins]: The motion passes.

[Collins]: So this draft language will be referred to the building commissioner, IT director, and PDS director, and we'll get their expert feedback on it before we make any moves to fold this into our comprehensive zoning update so that this can also be updated while we're doing potentially other zoning changes.

[Collins]: Is there any other discussion on this topic before we move on to our second paper for the night, either from councilors or from members of the public?

[Collins]: All right.

[Collins]: Hearing none, let's proceed along to paper 24008.

[Collins]: This is the resolution that the city council review the fee schedule.

[Collins]: of the city of Medford and look for areas to modernize and update.

[Collins]: My understanding is that the intention of this resolution is to look across many departments, like any departments for whom it's relevant.

[Collins]: Many departments charge fees for various things that they do in the city, such as issuing a marriage license or registering your car, getting residential parking permit.

[Collins]: And in many departments, it's been a long time since those fees were updated and changed.

[Collins]: And it's my understanding that in many departments, the fees that we charge are perhaps lower than they should be to correlate with the administrative cost of doing those functions.

[Collins]: And they might also be very out of step with what similar municipalities are charging for the same functions.

[Collins]: I don't think the intent here is to make any astronomical changes, but just to do a standard review

[Collins]: since one has not been done in, I think, many years, to see where are those glaring spots where things really need to be updated.

[Collins]: And I think one of the questions before us at this early stage is to say where all of the fee schedules for all of the departments are on the table, what departments do we want to look at specifically, and who are we requesting feedback and context from at this time?

[Collins]: But for further table setting, President Bears, do you have anything else you want to

[Collins]: and as the paper sponsor at this time?

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Collins]: I think the timeline sounds right.

[Collins]: You know, I imagine, you know, trying to put myself in the position of a

[Collins]: Department head looking at this, I'm sure that there are some of those fees where what it is and what it should be will jump out as obvious, and others where it will take a little bit of calculation.

[Collins]: What is the administrative cost incurred?

[Collins]: What would a more appropriate number be to do that research into what neighboring communities are charging to make sure that it's consistent with our regional neighbors?

[Collins]: I'm going to go to Councilor Callahan, and then I see Planner Evans' hand raised on Zoom.

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan?

[Collins]: I'll go now to Planner Evans on Zoom.

[Collins]: Thank you very much, Daniel.

[Collins]: I think that's really helpful for President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you, Planner Everins.

[Collins]: President Bears, I appreciate this discussion.

[Collins]: It seems like there's plenty of organization that would be helpful to both city staff and potentially developers and other people and entities that

[Collins]: trying to do the functions that incur fees to make it more clear what we're working with, where it lives.

[Collins]: And on the city side, part of the overall effort is not only to update some fees that are at least a decade, if not several decades out of date.

[Collins]: But I think in all of this, we're always trying to look at, is the procedure by which we update this the one that makes sense?

[Collins]: And so I'm glad that we're also thinking

[Collins]: you know, getting straight on for the different fees, for the different functions.

[Collins]: Is it by ordinance?

[Collins]: Is it by rule of regulation?

[Collins]: Set by a board that doesn't have to go through an ordinance?

[Collins]: And I'd be interested, as we're doing this review, just to see what options we have.

[Collins]: I think it's always, for myself as one Councilor, for something like fees where we're trying to make sure that it stays up to date, it is sometimes helpful to

[Collins]: consider if we have other non-ordinance mechanisms for doing that, so there doesn't have to be a legislation every time to keep something, you know, proceeding with, you know, cost of inflation.

[Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: As we're, I think that we're going to be collecting input and feedback on ideas for a lot of departments and boards on this.

[Collins]: And it's my hope that as we're going through and updating the fees themselves, we could also be

[Collins]: you know, as it's been mentioned, working to get all of the fees in the same place right now, it's really, it's pretty disorganized with a lot of things existing in other appendices on different webpages.

[Collins]: I think it'd be helpful to have all the fees in the same appendix.

[Collins]: Councilor Kellihan.

[Collins]: Any other questions or comments from councilors at this time?

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Collins]: I definitely agree with the intent of that.

[Collins]: I'd also like to know if it's possible for us to institute an annual percentage increase to a fee by ordinance, regardless of the percentage of that fee.

[Collins]: Do I have a second?

[Collins]: I'll second.

[Collins]: President Bears.

[Collins]: Seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Mr. Clerk, whenever you're ready.

[Collins]: That motion passes.

[Collins]: And I want to give a moment to prepare, or sorry, there was a motion from Councilor Leming to ask legal counsel if it is possible to institute an annual percentage increase to a fee that is set by ordinance.

[Collins]: Do I have a second on that motion?

[Collins]: Seconded by President Bears.

[Collins]: Can we increase a fee by a percentage?

[Collins]: Yes.

[Collins]: Four in favor, one opposed.

[Collins]: The motion passes.

[Collins]: Do I have a second on that motion?

[Collins]: Second from Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: Do I have a second on that motion?

[Collins]: Councilor Kelly.

[Collins]: Second.

[Collins]: And Councilor Scarpel.

[Collins]: Great, on the first motion from President Bears, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Mr. Clerk, whenever you're ready, please call the roll.

[Collins]: Yes.

[Collins]: Yes.

[Collins]: Five in favor, none opposed, the motion passes.

[Collins]: And on the

[Collins]: Second motion from President Bears, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Hotly pursued by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Collins]: Whenever you're ready, Mr. Clerk.

[Collins]: President Bears?

[Collins]: Yes.
