[Collins]: Thank you, Chair Lehmann.

[Collins]: With those motions behind us, I just wanted to thank Innes Associates, the whole team, for the first time joining us in committee to talk about the zoning revocation, sorry, the zoning overhaul.

[Collins]: I'm like 2022 over here.

[Collins]: As we've all stated, really excited to be continuing this project with you.

[Collins]: I know we're going to spend many evenings in the chambers and on Zoom together, putting all of these ideas and proposals and changes into our zoning code.

[Collins]: We are really glad to have you, speaking for myself, very glad to have you on board, excited to be doing this process with you.

[Collins]: Thank you for your time tonight and your preparation.

[Collins]: And thank you to my colleagues for coming prepared to kick off this project, which will certainly dominate the work of this committee this term.

[Collins]: I would motion to keep the paper in committee and adjourn.

[Collins]: Yes.

[Collins]: Present.

[Collins]: Thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Collins]: I apologize for having to be virtual tonight.

[Collins]: Can everybody hear me okay?

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: Let me know if the volume goes in and out at all.

[Collins]: So thank you for...

[Collins]: Having this be our main topic for tonight, I'm hoping that this will be a pretty straightforward discussion.

[Collins]: First, I'll offer a brief introduction, and then I can run us through the draft ordinance before us that I'm hoping we can use as a jumping off point.

[Collins]: Open it up to, you know, love to hear any comments from my fellow Councilors at this preliminary stage, comments from the community, and figure out some next steps that make sense for this community.

[Collins]: So the idea for a wildlife feeding ordinance came up based on some outreach from constituents that I got over the course of the year last year, talking about

[Collins]: some issues arising from overfeeding of wildlife in some of Medford's denser residential areas.

[Collins]: Looking around a little bit more, given the characteristics of some of Medford's denser residential neighborhoods, this is an issue that can cause public health nuisances whenever we have these

[Collins]: areas of the city with homes close together, if there's overfeeding of wildlife, we have permeable borders between our various homes and backyards and porches in the city.

[Collins]: So the intent of this is to give the Board of Health and Code Enforcement the ordinance tools that they need in order to issue warnings, tickets, potentially fines, whenever there's an issue arising from overfeeding of wildlife that neighbors cannot resolve amongst themselves.

[Collins]: I do want to emphasize that.

[Collins]: The intent here is just to empower code enforcement to step in when it's necessary to reduce a nuisance that's in line with other goals of the Board of Health and Code Enforcement to make sure that residents' enjoyment of the outdoors is enhanced and not limited.

[Collins]: So I want to be really clear from the beginning, this is not about saying you can't have a bird feeder.

[Collins]: This is about saying if there's feeding going on that's causing too many seagulls or pigeons or raccoons or rats

[Collins]: on somebody else's property.

[Collins]: That's something that if neighbors can't sort that out amongst themselves, then co-enforcement needs to be able to.

[Collins]: So this, I have a draft ordinance for us to look at as a jumping off point.

[Collins]: This language is based on several other communities ordinances that have similar goals.

[Collins]: The one that this is modeled most closely on is Westford, Mass.

[Collins]: So, Chair Lazzaro, if it's okay with you, I can run through the draft ordinance.

[Collins]: I'd be happy to share my screen, or if you'd like to, I can follow along.

[Collins]: That'd be great.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: Hang on one second, please.

[Collins]: All right.

[Collins]: Can everybody see where it says Wildlife Feeding Ordinance Draft 2.13?

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: So I'll just go through this pretty quickly.

[Collins]: This was in councilor's packets for this week, so I'm sure this isn't the first time that my colleagues are seeing this.

[Collins]: Standard ordinance format.

[Collins]: Up top, we start with purpose and intent, stating that Medford is, of course, as we all know and as we all cherish, Medford is home to a large population of wild animals, including rats, pigeons, bulls, and raccoons.

[Collins]: However, feeding such wildlife, whether on purpose or through neglect, can entice and attract wild animals onto private property.

[Collins]: porches, backyards.

[Collins]: And again, the emphasis here is on feeding occurring on one lot that is having adverse effects for either that lot or neighbors.

[Collins]: But limiting the practice of feeding wildlife, whether intentionally or passively, and enforcing this prohibition, the city can help limit a major factor that entices wildlife into resident areas of the city.

[Collins]: Again, not anti-wildlife.

[Collins]: We just want to make sure that every organism stays where it's most healthy for it to be.

[Collins]: We have a definition section just to make it clear what this is targeted towards and what it is not.

[Collins]: I think that the more useful thing in this section is going into some detail about what constitutes feeding, and based on some of the issues that this ordinance project arose out of, I think it's important to know that feeding doesn't just mean intentionally distributing food for wildlife, but potentially leaving inappropriate

[Collins]: wildlife food out in an area where realistically varmints are going to get to it.

[Collins]: So section C, prohibited activity, no person shall feed any wildlife as defined above, nor distribute or scatter any foodstuffs in or on any private place or, sorry, any public place or private property.

[Collins]: So this is a thing that we should not do because we know that it attracts wild animals into residential areas of the city.

[Collins]: I want to highlight some of the exceptions that are going in in this early draft of the ordinance.

[Collins]: Nothing in this section shall be interpreted so as to prohibit bird feeders.

[Collins]: There is an exception to the exception.

[Collins]: If it is appearing that a bird feeder is the cause of a public safety threat or nuisance, then perhaps the enforcing officer will step in and say, here's the cause of a nuisance.

[Collins]: This must be resolved.

[Collins]: I think that I personally have never heard of a case where a bird feeder is causing an issue.

[Collins]: This also states, nothing in this section shall be interpreted so as to prohibit the feeding of pets, provided that if food for pets is determined to be the source of wildlife feeding, then in that case, if it's causing an issue, that person may be directed to make sure that that food is no longer accessible to wildlife.

[Collins]: It also states, nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prohibit the storage of food products, pet food or any other material where it's not constituting an attraction to wildlife.

[Collins]: And again,

[Collins]: If a reasonable usage is resulting in an adverse effect, then in that case, if it's reported, if it's deemed to be an issue, the enforcing officer may say, this isn't necessarily an issue, but in this case, it's causing wildlife to come into your property or neighbor's property to an extent that is causing harm or might cause harm.

[Collins]: And then they might order them to remove it and store it in a more secure way.

[Collins]: Getting down to enforcement, I thought it'd be appropriate for the animal control officer, the health director, the code enforcement officers and their designees to share administration and enforcement of this ordinance.

[Collins]: There are some other wildlife-related enforcement responsibilities that the health director already has.

[Collins]: Obviously, this touches the purview of the animal control officer and code enforcement officers are often called upon to.

[Collins]: administer some of these nuisance-related issues on public and private property.

[Collins]: So I'd be curious to hear feedback from city staff on that, but I thought that was an appropriate place to start.

[Collins]: And finally, in terms of penalties for non-compliance, it is my hope that

[Collins]: But again, the goal of this, I think, is not to say, oh, you did something wrong.

[Collins]: Well, gosh, we'll ticket you immediately.

[Collins]: No.

[Collins]: The point of this is to provide a recourse for when something is going wrong and neighbors aren't able to resolve it amongst themselves immediately.

[Collins]: So I would hope that, as with our other ordinances at the discretion of the enforcing officers, sometimes this is a warning.

[Collins]: Sometimes this is a written warning, an oral warning.

[Collins]: Sometimes it escalates to a ticket if the issue is really not getting resolved.

[Collins]: And in that case,

[Collins]: You know, based on that, I have in this first draft, first offense is a written warning from an enforcing officer.

[Collins]: Second offense, $50 ticket.

[Collins]: Third and subsequent offenses, $100 ticket.

[Collins]: And of course, per MGL, we are not able to charge more than a $300 ticket, I believe, for any civil code violation.

[Collins]: And I think it makes sense.

[Collins]: Again, this is supposed to be a deterrent, not something punitive.

[Collins]: So I thought this could be good to hear my fellow Councilors' feedback.

[Collins]: I'm not part of the audience and anything else.

[Collins]: I also want to note before I stop talking and let my fellow Councilors respond to that, at our last meeting of the Public Health and Community Safety Committee, I did

[Collins]: mentioned this ordinance, and as a follow-up, the clerk did circulate the ordinance to my fellow councilors and to relevant city staff requesting their feedback by March 15th.

[Collins]: That was when I thought that the next meeting of this committee was going to be in April.

[Collins]: The council meeting schedule changed since then, so the word has already been put out to relevant city staff to get their comment on that, and we'll be sure to have it by the next time that we meet on this ordinance.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I really appreciate my fellow Councilors initial reactions to this.

[Collins]: Thank you for taking this project so thoughtfully.

[Collins]: initial reaction to the questions around, and I think it's a really good question, like how does this intersect with efforts to make sure that wildcats are attracted so that they can be spayed and neutered, which is important.

[Collins]: There's a couple areas in the ordinance, and I appreciate Councilor Callaghan for speaking to this, where it might be covered, but I think that that would be a great thing to put to our animal control officer, as well as to have legal counsel take a look at when they do their review of this, just to make sure.

[Collins]: that that should be would be interpreted the way that we intend.

[Collins]: And again, the intent of this is to

[Collins]: make sure that there's a recourse for when something is causing an issue, that there's a way for the code enforcement officer to step in.

[Collins]: But I think that this is creating a good succinct list of questions to follow up with our staff and experts.

[Collins]: And I would also be happy to, I'll probably make some motions at the end of our discussion, I'd also be happy to make sure that

[Collins]: the Medford-based group, Kitty Connection, sees a copy of this just to make sure that it is on their radars as folks in the community who do work with wildlife.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Chair Lazzaro?

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I'll answer to either.

[Collins]: I would make a motion to refer this version of the ordinance to KP Law for a legal review prior to our next meeting on the topic.

[Collins]: That would be my first motion.

[Collins]: Yes, thank you.

[Collins]: I have two more.

[Collins]: Second motion would be to have the city clerk recirculate this document to the relevant city staff, along with the questions that came out of this committee discussion, mainly around if this covers putting out food to trap feral cats for spaying and neutering.

[Collins]: And then I would also motion to keep this paper in committee.

[Collins]: I'm happy to defer to a presentation by a member of the administration, President Bearsford.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you to my fellow Councilors for their comments on this.

[Collins]: I just want to note that this is the second time that a Stabilization Fund paper has come before us.

[Collins]: Last year, the administration submitted a similar but different paper.

[Collins]: At that time, we decided that creating that structure and making a large appropriation all in one fell swoop was not the right timing for the city.

[Collins]: This time, the paper comes to us

[Collins]: After months of ongoing discussions about this city's financial future, those discussions must and will continue.

[Collins]: I do believe that it is the best practice for cities like Medford to have a rainy day fund, in the same way that many households have a rainy day fund for unforeseen emergencies.

[Collins]: I think that this is an appropriate time to create the structure and then subsequently have those conversations about how much is appropriate to put into the fund and when, because this paper does not call for an appropriation, simply the creation of the structure.

[Collins]: I also want to note this, to just reemphasize, there's no money changing accounts in this paper.

[Collins]: If there were to be, it would be a reappropriation of money already in the city's coffers and the community's coffers.

[Collins]: I think that this is the right time to set up the structure and then again have those community conversations about how much it makes sense to put into that rainy day fund.

[Collins]: And when the next time we have these community wide emergencies come up, we are better prepared to take care of Medford residents.

[Collins]: I would motion for approval.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I want to thank Councilor Leming for co-sponsoring this proposal with me.

[Collins]: I'll try to be as brief as I can.

[Collins]: Housing affordability, unaffordability continues to displace Medford residents from where we grew up, went to school, the communities that we worship in, study, have community ties where we go to work.

[Collins]: It is becoming more and more out of the question for working class and middle class people to live here, and no one is going to swoop in and fix that for us.

[Collins]: I know that Medford residents deeply value being a welcoming and diverse community.

[Collins]: The question is, are we willing to have the conversations and utilize the tools that will help us keep it that way?

[Collins]: If we want our Affordable Housing Trust Fund to be more than a talking point, we know that we need to create dedicated funding streams so that it can manifest in housing and programs that will make it possible for us to keep Medford residents in Medford and for us to welcome new neighbors.

[Collins]: Real estate transfer fees are one tool that the Governor has indicated provisional support for.

[Collins]: That's why we're proposing to consider it.

[Collins]: Our methods for meaningfully funding affordable housing are too few and far between to dismiss this out of hand, and our existing funding streams, including CPA, are unfortunately insufficient on their own.

[Collins]: The scale is too great.

[Collins]: Displacement is already happening.

[Collins]: As Councilwoman said, what's before us tonight is whether we want to have the conversation about how to tailor this tool to dedicate a small percentage of only the highest ticket real estate transactions towards the most underinvested in housing in our community, the housing we desperately need and have a very severe shortage of.

[Collins]: I want to be clear, if we vote this into committee tonight, then we can and we will get into the weeds with the community.

[Collins]: We can discuss how to tailor this to affect the appropriate type of highest value sales so as to capture a small percentage of the huge value increases that have come into this region as living in Medford and places like it has become more expensive and more desirable.

[Collins]: We can consider exceptions, like for elders, for people making transfers to close family, or for people selling at a loss or at minimal profit.

[Collins]: Essentially, we can go through what would need to happen in order for this to be a net positive for this community.

[Collins]: And then I want to remind everybody, this would need approval from the mayor, our state delegation, as well as the governor for this to actually take effect.

[Collins]: I want to be really clear, we are not implementing a tax tonight.

[Collins]: We are proposing to send this idea to committee to start a conversation, and I believe it is a very necessary conversation.

[Collins]: I thank my fellow councilors and the public for their time.

[Collins]: I will motion for approval.

[Collins]: You know what, I'll follow up with Mr. Castagnetti after the meeting to thank him for sending along that New York Times Post article.

[Collins]: Appreciate it.

[Collins]: And I just think it speaks to the point that we need to be pursuing every tool at our disposal when it comes to affordable housing that can work for everybody.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Um, this is an ordinance that I've worked on over my terms and city council I believe this is an exercise and compromise is the result of what we have put forward over a couple years of working on this hearing.

[Collins]: strong opposition to the idea of regulating these devices and also very strong support for the idea of mitigating these devices that we know cause significant air pollution and also noise pollution.

[Collins]: What we've arrived at is an ordinance that seeks to provide some reasonable constraints around which devices can be used,

[Collins]: at what times of the day, where, and phases out the most polluting versions of these devices, gas-powered, for residential and commercial users over different timescales over the next several years.

[Collins]: I do have one motion before we vote, which is Section 3858, subsection 2,

[Collins]: think that the word continuous should be removed.

[Collins]: A constituent got in touch and indicated that this created kind of a loophole that was counter to the goals of this section.

[Collins]: So that would be to remove the word continuous from section 3858 subsection 2 before we vote.

[Collins]: section 38, 58, and then numeral two in that section.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Essentially, what I put in my memo speaks to my recommendations.

[Collins]: My priority is for this budget cycle.

[Collins]: This is not going to be a budget year where I think that we are having the bandwidth to pilot a lot of new programs or start a lot of new positions.

[Collins]: My focus is on maintaining level service for constituents and for students and workers in school systems.

[Collins]: That's why my number one and number two priorities are meeting the school department budget request and meeting the library department budget request, making sure that we maintain level service and hours of operation at the library in particular, because that has been something that has been called into question in some past budget cycles.

[Collins]: I wanted to call out specifically grant-funded personnel in the Health Department, Office of Outreach and Prevention, and the Planning Department because there are a lot of grant-funded positions in those departments specifically, but we know that all those positions are critical.

[Collins]: In our community, they serve really important functions and the needs for those roles are not going away just because pandemic-era funding and grant funding is going away, so we need to make sure that we are maintaining level service by

[Collins]: rolling those positions either onto other sources of grant funding or ideally making sure that those positions can be maintained within our operations, our operating budget this year and in future years.

[Collins]: The next few key priorities for this year are ones that we've talked about around this time of year in the past.

[Collins]: Trying to get a city solicitor and an assistant city solicitor online as quickly as we can.

[Collins]: It's my belief that we need to raise the amount budgeted for salary for those positions so that we can be attracting competitive candidates.

[Collins]: I do believe that this is a at this moment in time a tough position to hire for in this area in, in general, and I think that these positions are so important that we should prioritize escalating the amount of salary budgeted for these positions, so that

[Collins]: we are competitive with some of our neighboring municipalities.

[Collins]: I put some recommended dollar figures on here.

[Collins]: Those are based off of my research into what our neighboring communities of Malden and Somerville primarily are paying for these positions.

[Collins]: For example, in Malden, the budgeted salary for their city solicitor is around, it's a little over 117,000.

[Collins]: In Somerville, it's 189.

[Collins]: I believe that the figure I suggested to increase the city solicitor salary by less than $50,000 was based on the discrepancy with Malden.

[Collins]: Is that true?

[Collins]: Oh, sorry.

[Collins]: That was based off the discrepancy with the city of Somerville.

[Collins]: I know this is a big jump for one position, but I think we've all felt for the past few years how significant it is to not have a city solicitor in-house, and I think that that would be a

[Collins]: I think that we can be pound wise by investing more money into these unfilled city positions.

[Collins]: It's the same for the assistant city solicitor and in escalating the elections manager to a direct deliver position again I think that these are things that you know we see what happens when we don't invest in making sure that

[Collins]: these positions are first and foremost filled.

[Collins]: And second, you know, we really owe the people of Medford, the best possible person in all of these roles.

[Collins]: And then I put the secondary priorities under areas of study slash secondary priorities.

[Collins]: I know that these are things we're not going to be able to bring online early in fiscal 25.

[Collins]: But I think that charting a course towards implementing a paid family and medical leave program for all city employees, apart from being the right thing to do and what all of our city employees deserve will help us

[Collins]: fill key staffing roles.

[Collins]: And I believe that a review of what needs to happen to bring our finance department software into the 2020s is something that we would see the benefit from.

[Collins]: Once we achieve that, we need to figure out if that's something that can happen in three, five, or 10 years.

[Collins]: And I think that every department would feel the positive effects of that.

[Collins]: So I'm hoping that

[Collins]: while not being things that I think are realistic to prioritize for fiscal 25, these are things that I hope that the administration is saving some capacity for studying this year.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears, and I thank all of my fellow councillors for coming into the meeting with their recommendations.

[Collins]: I think it's really exciting that we're starting this conversation in March for the first time in

[Collins]: the first time that I've been on the council, which is not that long, but I think that this conversation, this process is beginning earlier than it usually does.

[Collins]: And I appreciate the administration's cooperation so far with trying to make the overall budgeting process more communicative and less rushed.

[Collins]: And I think that this is a great start.

[Collins]: I'm happy to hear that there's cohesion among a lot of us on a lot of the shared priorities, and I think that's not surprising because we hear all the same issues.

[Collins]: And I think that when I think back over the past couple years of budget discussions and what the common threads that emerge are, you know, we're the funnel into which sort of the main problems and aspirations and grievances of the city

[Collins]: comes into.

[Collins]: And I think the conversation that we've been having about the law department for a couple of years is an example of this.

[Collins]: We're seeing our capacity reduced within these chambers because we lack in-house legal support.

[Collins]: We see it taking a lot of time on ordinances.

[Collins]: We see legal issues coming up, like the BJ's lawsuit, as Councilor Scarpelli mentioned.

[Collins]: And I think the work of this council, very productive in the past, has been to say, what's the common denominator here?

[Collins]: What's the investment that we're not making that we need to make that could be the fulcrum for all this other change?

[Collins]: If we had a staffed in-house legal department, I think we would be seeing the difference in our workflow, in the quality of our workflow, and how quickly we're able to get things done, and then there would be all the things that we are not seeing.

[Collins]: All of the decisions that

[Collins]: It's hard to make, or we have to put off, or we have to request from an outside legal perspective, and they're not super accountable to their timelines, to our timelines, because they don't work for us.

[Collins]: It's all the negatives that we don't see because of a targeted investment, in addition to all the positives that we do start to see.

[Collins]: I think that's still that common denominator that we're still looking for that targeted investment there.

[Collins]: And I think the other one that this conversation, um, I would say over the past six months is also revealing is needed investments to the finance department.

[Collins]: I think president bears put it very well.

[Collins]: There's all these positives that we would start to see if we brought our financial software and staffing up to year 2024.

[Collins]: And then there's all these negatives that once we stop having these problems and inefficiencies and, you know,

[Collins]: deleted results that come from a severe shortage of staffing and outdated software.

[Collins]: We won't know it when those problems start to go away, but we're certainly seeing them now.

[Collins]: And it's exciting to me to see multiple voices in this room,

[Collins]: noticing the same problems.

[Collins]: And I think that we're identifying another area, like the legal department, that we really need the administration to target some investment into.

[Collins]: I know that it's hard to contemplate in this financial environment, making a multi-million dollar investment.

[Collins]: But as President Beer said,

[Collins]: We're already spending a lot, not just in money, but in staff time on trying to use inefficient processes to do this work that we have to do anyway, and dealing with the problems that arise from doing it less efficiently than we have to.

[Collins]: So I hope that that can be a topic that we really elevate this budget season.

[Collins]: Again, this is a year when I think we have to be realistic, but I think that this is so foundational to so many departments that we can't afford to not

[Collins]: prioritize the issue and at least try to get some, you know, in my recommendations, I put it forward as an area of study.

[Collins]: Can we at least invest in a consultant to look at our software and say, here's a plan for how to get there?

[Collins]: Can we at least start there?

[Collins]: If not looking at what would it look to really divert some funding into an investment in this fiscal year and know that that's

[Collins]: something that might feel short-term uncomfortable, but we have to think about the long-term downstream positive effects of that kind of investment.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Barras.

[Collins]: My preference in terms of where we go from here, I think that we built in a couple of weeks to move from individual council recommendations to full council recommendations.

[Collins]: I think this meeting put us in a pretty good,

[Collins]: I think that there's a very clear.

[Collins]: Ben diagram.

[Collins]: There's a lot of stuff in the middle.

[Collins]: Personally I would be comfortable with the process where either this kind of informal document is shared out by the clerk to all Councilors and Councilors get back to the clerk with perhaps a ranking of their.

[Collins]: Top five, which as council leadership, you or I could assimilate into a document for us to vote on in a future committee of the whole, um, I think that it would be a pretty similar process if, um.

[Collins]: you know, I think that we could, um.

[Collins]: Yourself for myself.

[Collins]: Um just took a stab at, you know, tallying up what was submitted the most times make a version of that document, and then we could similarly look at it as a group at a future committee of the whole and then make some final decisions.

[Collins]: Um that evening and still have plenty of time to submit it before the 22nd.

[Collins]: I just think that that will be, um, give Councilors time to digest, um,

[Collins]: without some time to order our rankings.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I think that's an important question, especially for the folks for whom this is the first budget season.

[Collins]: And I appreciate

[Collins]: President Bears' overview of what I think is a reasonable way to approach this.

[Collins]: In terms of

[Collins]: what I would propose we, you know, what we literally send to the administration.

[Collins]: I believe that what we did last year, probably the year before that as well, we go through this process of Councilors submitting individual recommendations.

[Collins]: We talk about our shared priorities.

[Collins]: We come to some form of consensus about, we all come in with our individual rankings, individual priorities, and we find what is the middle of that Venn diagram.

[Collins]: What are the things that we're going to say?

[Collins]: There's 30 things we want.

[Collins]: We're going to ask for five and hopefully get one or two.

[Collins]: And trying to hone in on those shared areas of most importance.

[Collins]: So that's, I think, the first page of the packet.

[Collins]: And then I think what we did last year was we also included every Councilor's individual memos.

[Collins]: And I would propose that we also, of course, include the minutes of these meetings so that the administration has

[Collins]: you know, that thorough overview of our discussion, has the record of everything that we put on the table, everything that we thought was important to raise.

[Collins]: In addition to, out of all of that, here's that shorter list of things that we really have to say.

[Collins]: And so, in terms of next steps from here, I think that

[Collins]: I believe that we have some space in the schedule to have a follow up committee of the whole to revisit this before the 22nd.

[Collins]: If fellow Councilors were amenable to it I'd be happy to make a motion for council leadership to

[Collins]: circulate this aggregated document among fellow Councilors.

[Collins]: By the end of the week, work to schedule a follow-up committee of the whole where we can digest it together, come up with a shared shortlist of priorities so that we can stick to that timeline of submitting it to the administration by the 22nd along with Councilors individual memos and the records of this meeting.

[Collins]: to circulate the document for council leadership to schedule a follow-up committee of the whole where we will prioritize those ideas, and then to submit that list of priorities to the administration by the 22nd after the meeting, along with councilors' individual memos and the records of our meetings on the topic.

[Collins]: Yeah.

[Collins]: Planning and Permanent Committee, February 28, 2024.

[Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6 p.m.

[Collins]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall and via Zoom.

[Collins]: Mr. Clerk, would you please call the roll?

[Collins]: Planning and Permitting Committee.

[Collins]: The action and discussion item for this meeting is paper 24042, a resolution to discuss the implementation of the Housing Stability Notification Ordinance.

[Collins]: And we've invited some members of the Planning, Development and Sustainability Office that are the staff that are tasked with implementing and enforcing

[Collins]: this ordinance to be with us here tonight.

[Collins]: I just want to make it clear, because this is a resolution to discuss the implementation of an ordinance that was passed around this time last year.

[Collins]: The Housing Stability Notification Ordinance is an ordinance that was passed in February 2023 that created a new requirement for

[Collins]: property owners of properties where there are tenants, that at the beginning and end of any lease, that they should send a document that is created by the City of Medford detailing tenants' resources and tenants' rights to those tenants at those given

[Collins]: start and end times to any lease.

[Collins]: That is the ordinance in a nutshell.

[Collins]: It's fairly simple.

[Collins]: We had a fairly lengthy process crafting the ordinance between 2022 and 2023.

[Collins]: Now it's been about a year since we passed it, so the purpose of this meeting is to check in

[Collins]: with the Planning, Development, and Sustainability Office that have been working hard, thinking about how it makes sense to roll out this ordinance, going through the necessary steps to put together that document, to draft it, to run it by legal counsel, and to be thoughtful about how to make sure that everybody in the community that ought to know about this new requirement does before we officially begin implementing and following up with people to ensure that it's being complied with.

[Collins]: So with that, I'm going to open it up to preliminary comment from my fellow councillors that I'd love to hear just an overall update from our city staff.

[Collins]: Any comments from my fellow councillors?

[Collins]: Hearing none, I'd be happy to turn it over to Director of Planning, Development and Sustainability, Alicia Hunt, and our housing planner, Aditi, to give us an update on the

[Collins]: You know, I know that there's been a lot of good work being done in the planning office to develop this document and to think through how we're gonna roll it out.

[Collins]: So I'd love any sort of update that you can share on that process.

[Collins]: I'll quickly chime in, and then I'll turn it back over to our subject matter experts.

[Collins]: My understanding, and I appreciate that question, Councilor Scarpellirilli, because I think that's an important point to clarify.

[Collins]: My understanding is this

[Collins]: ordinance adds something to that process.

[Collins]: So the state law creates a requirement for that document and that required notice and resources to be sent when there is a notice to quit.

[Collins]: This ordinance says not necessarily just when there's an ordinance, sorry, when there's a notice to quit, but when a lease is beginning or when a lease is ending for other reasons.

[Collins]: Let's make sure

[Collins]: Right.

[Collins]: If there's a foreclosure happening, let's make sure that the person occupying that home or about to occupy that home knows their rights and has these resources in those other scenarios as well, building on top of the state law that is specifically about notices to quit.

[Collins]: Did I get that right, Director?

[Collins]: Councilor Leming?

[Collins]: Yeah.

[Collins]: And if I, I appreciate, um, I,

[Collins]: One of the goals of this meeting is just a general update of where we are at in rolling out the implementation.

[Collins]: I think the other, especially now that it's been a year since we were talking about this in public meeting, is to have these clarifying conversations about what is the intent of this and what does it do and what are the consequences and what aren't the consequences.

[Collins]: So, you know, as the sponsor of the original ordinance now passed,

[Collins]: I think that there is nothing about the notification document that would affect eviction proceedings at all.

[Collins]: I don't think that there's anything about the notification document that would... The intent of the document is to be something that can go to a tenant and say,

[Collins]: Here's some info.

[Collins]: If you have an issue, here's who you can call.

[Collins]: You have a question, here's who you can call.

[Collins]: If you have a question and this is the language you speak and it's not English, here's who you can call just to be informative.

[Collins]: And the intent of that is to really make sure that people are empowered with information before they have any sort of issue or problem, which is intended to be.

[Collins]: beneficial for a tenant or property owner, everybody in that relationship.

[Collins]: So on the enforcement side, I don't think this would ever impact, you know, should a notice to quit be issued.

[Collins]: If there's another condition that prompts an eviction, this would not affect that timeline.

[Collins]: And I think we put it very clearly in the ordinance.

[Collins]: You know, this is something that is intended to be an informative and educational ordinance, not something that we're going to be

[Collins]: looking and looking for evidence of non-compliance to issue tickets, but rather to be something that we can follow up and saying, let's make sure that everybody gets the information before they need it, and that our city staff can be working proactively to make sure that this is getting out to the community in an accessible way.

[Collins]: So I really appreciate the opportunity to clarify that.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, Alicia.

[Collins]: I appreciate that approach.

[Collins]: I think that, like we said, the goal of this is to be informative, if we all recognize that a healthy tenant-landlord relationship is one where everybody knows what their responsibilities are and their resources are, tenants included, and know what to expect and what to expect of themselves.

[Collins]: And that's the best recipe for a healthy and unproblematic relationship.

[Collins]: I saw President Bears, Councilor Leming, and then back to you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Collins]: Is that a cover your questions?

[Collins]: That's great.

[Collins]: Thank you, Director.

[Collins]: And it's exciting to hear about different ways of collaborating with, you know, not just property owners, but also real estate agents in the city to make sure that all these initiatives and all the good work that I think everybody wants to be doing, that we can be staying on the same page and synthesizing about that.

[Collins]: I'll go to the housing planner and then Councilor Bears.

[Collins]: All right, thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bearsens, and I appreciate, you know, when we were developing this ordinance over the course of several months leading up to, I think we passed it in February 2023, most of our conversations were centered around how do we make this something that is accessible, that people can understand, that people who don't read English can language, can access in the language they understand.

[Collins]: Essentially, how do we make this tool that is meant to be informational, how do we make it easy to access?

[Collins]: And I really appreciate, you know, now that we're talking about

[Collins]: I appreciate that City staff is taking the time to make sure that this is done right in that same spirit of we want to make sure that everybody who needs to know that this is a new requirement hears about it.

[Collins]: And I appreciate that we're thinking through the communication channels that the city already uses, that the conversation is starting with.

[Collins]: What can we use to physically get this into people's hands?

[Collins]: Because we know it's probably a fraction of all Medford residents and property owners that are on the city's

[Collins]: social media channels and accessing what local news we have left.

[Collins]: And so I appreciate that those are, you know, perhaps going to be supplementary tools to getting this information out, but that primarily we're thinking through.

[Collins]: you know, what's the best mailing to use so that this is cost-effective that we make sure that people hear about it.

[Collins]: And I was especially happy to hear that staff is thinking in the direction of, you know, the mailing that will go out to property owners will include sort of a signal, like, there is a new requirement to send out a document.

[Collins]: This is not that document.

[Collins]: That document lives online.

[Collins]: Like, here's how to access it.

[Collins]: Here's how to print it out.

[Collins]: Here's how to send it to the library and get it printed out, rather than sending a static document that then

[Collins]: we'll get photocopied until it's illegible or we'll get updated and people won't benefit from that updated information and so on.

[Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Collins]: Do I have a second on the motion to keep the paper in committee and reconvene for another update, perhaps on timeline as we get later into the spring?

[Collins]: Second from Councilor Leming.

[Collins]: What are the questions still on the table for finalizing the document and then alerting everybody who ought to be alerted about it?

[Collins]: I know that there's some energy to try to get the document finalized and begin to roll that out, you know, this spring, by June, I think.

[Collins]: Just to echo what my colleagues just shared, I think the

[Collins]: You know, I certainly share the concern.

[Collins]: It's very important to not be legislating something that we don't know is within our capacity or beyond our capacity.

[Collins]: And I definitely appreciate the focus on that as we're still crafting this in draft form.

[Collins]: And I completely agree to me the intent of the language that's currently in that section of the ordinance is just to create kind of some sort of timestamp for a check-in.

[Collins]: I know the term report usually connotated as like a very structured, very detailed, like it must have X, Y, and Z type of document.

[Collins]: To me, the intent is just to make sure that once a year we have some kind of record of here's where we were last year, here's where we are this year in terms of

[Collins]: are we approaching it?

[Collins]: What new tools have we developed?

[Collins]: What is our sense right now of what we might need to get closer to that goal?

[Collins]: And not some sort of mandate, not some sort of, you know, if it doesn't have this section, then it's invalid or something like that.

[Collins]: A fairly, you know, the phrase I would use, I wouldn't put this in the ordinances, I would be pretty comfortable with this being as formal or as informal as possible.

[Collins]: capacity allows it to be while we're trying to get this annual process off the ground.

[Collins]: That's important to me is just knowing that we're going to have some kind of document and some kind of check-in in the fall every year that allows us to chart our progress towards the better information and the sophistication that I know the administration is already working towards and that we're eager to support.

[Collins]: You know everything that the chief of staff has shared in this meeting and other and others.

[Collins]: And I think that, you know, as a city, we see how that plays out with our various challenges and episodes and things that we go through in trying to manage our capacity as a city overall.

[Collins]: One thing that, again, and I respect the diversity of opinion about the exact language that this section is put into, one thing that makes me personally feel comfortable is just how flexible the language of this section is.

[Collins]: And of course, I've made it clear before, you know, that in my mind, this says, you know, shall submit a report and doesn't really get prescriptive about what that has to look like beyond touching on certain topics.

[Collins]: It does bring to mind to me because the Chief of Staff mentioned the Elections Department in terms of, you know, I think this conversation is a lot about thinking through contingencies.

[Collins]: What about the years when this report isn't like all that we would dream it to be?

[Collins]: Quite recently, the City Council asked for an elections after action report from the Elections Department and that report was not all that we dreamed it to be.

[Collins]: So we talked about it and

[Collins]: And that was how we took that document and got some meaning out of it by, you know, that spring conversation about, you know, this is what we would like to see in it.

[Collins]: Next time, these are the questions that we still have.

[Collins]: The conversation that we had about the report, I think, answered a little bit more some of those questions that weren't answered in the text of it.

[Collins]: So I just bring that up as an example of

[Collins]: um, why I feel comfortable with this language, knowing that, you know, I don't know, like, maybe we'll never have a season of going through this process laid out in the, uh, laid out in the ordinance where it will feel very challenging to do that.

[Collins]: Maybe it'll feel, feel seamless, you know, starting this fall, maybe it won't.

[Collins]: Um, but

[Collins]: if it's not seamless, if there's friction there, if it's challenging to get a report together, if the report, like, has to be very concise, if the report has to be really bare bones the first year, if, you know, we read the report and we still have questions, well, I feel like we already have a model for how that can go.

[Collins]: And I think that even just having a simple document to start out with, that's a jumping off point for a discussion in committee or written follow-up, to me, that's still productive to have, even if

[Collins]: that conversation is about what's not included.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I appreciate the overview since we looked at this last and since this is the first time that we're meeting about this in this current term.

[Collins]: It's helpful to have the overview.

[Collins]: I think that the comments that we've received from KP Law

[Collins]: and some other partners have been helpful to get this closer to a finished product.

[Collins]: In terms of starting at the beginning, you know, with the goals of this ordinance, I think it's clear throughout this process, you know, we've kind of tacked our way into a middle path between, you know, the goals of phasing out

[Collins]: a very polluting technology while making sure that this is something that is manageable from an enforcement standpoint on the city side to make sure that it's a manageable time frame for large properties and commercial users to make sure that we're

[Collins]: balancing the right regulations and restrictions for commercial users and for private users.

[Collins]: And I think that our process has benefited a lot from hearing from constituents and commercial users in the past and hopefully tonight as well, as well as the Chamber of Commerce and making sure that we've been tailoring and tweaking this so that it's

[Collins]: fair for different use cases.

[Collins]: And over the past couple of versions, we've also kind of tweaked that in terms of what specific restrictions we're putting forward and also what metrics and measures we're using.

[Collins]: whether it's the amount of months in the year that we allow use of the gas-powered leaf blowers versus electric, whether it's what we're using to measure if something is within allowable ranges or not.

[Collins]: I'm glad to see kind of on that seam of fairness, making sure that this is fair for different types of users.

[Collins]: I'm glad that we have removed some of the exemptions for municipal use of the leaf blowers.

[Collins]: I think that anything that we're expecting of commercial users, we should expect of municipal contractors as well.

[Collins]: So that's something that I'm happy to see.

[Collins]: And I'm happy to see that this, I think, is the most readable version of the ordinance that we've had yet, which is, of course, super important because some of the people using this ordinance are just, a lot of them are just homeowners, residents who just want to know, is this okay?

[Collins]: You know, is this what my community has in mind for, you know, reality testing?

[Collins]: Is this a reasonable time to use this tool this time of the year?

[Collins]: Or I could just do it right now.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: point in this ordinance where we can think about finalizing it, reporting it out to committee.

[Collins]: focus in on any aspects in this meeting if we need to, to make sure that everybody is feeling comfortable and up to speed before we take next steps on this.

[Collins]: Towards that, I have a few motions to incorporate some of the suggestions from legal counsel.

[Collins]: Let me just orient myself here.

[Collins]: In section 3858,

[Collins]: Otherwise, we're just referring to blowing leaves.

[Collins]: So I would motion to delete sweep or rake, which is the suggestion made in the red line copy.

[Collins]: And the intent there is just, you know, we've done a lot of work to make this ordinance more readable and very clear in its intent, especially for, you know, there's a wide range of people who are gonna be consulting this, city staff, contractors, residents.

[Collins]: And we, I think, you know, simplicity is always of the essence so that two people reading the same document get the same impression out of it.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: In the same section 3858 subsection 6.

[Collins]: It was noted that, so this says deposits of leaf, dirt, dust, et cetera, shall be removed and disposed of in a sanitary manner, which will prevent it from being dispersed by wind vandalism or similar means.

[Collins]: A little confusing.

[Collins]: I think that rather than trying to define what sanitary matter means, I would,

[Collins]: Sorry.

[Collins]: Motion to delete in a sanitary manner and replace that with in such a manner so that it reused shall be removed and disposed of in such a manner which will prevent it from dot, dot, dot.

[Collins]: And I'm happy to pause.

[Collins]: Yes.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: And then I have a couple.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: I think it's fair to say it's something we've discussed.

[Collins]: No, I just said that we did actually.

[Collins]: I think we found that it's still worthwhile to put forward this ordinance that is targeted at specifically two-stroke engines, which are known to be one of the most polluting types.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you for everybody who's spoken tonight and in previous meetings for and against.

[Collins]: You know, I can only speak for myself as one Councilor, this isn't the project that I initiated it was initiated by former President Morell know that all of our projects come out of constituent feedback.

[Collins]: You know, from one form or another, this is one of those projects.

[Collins]: You know, I think that this project is really the product of compromise, like a lot of like almost like every single one of our ordinances and resolutions and projects in this chambers.

[Collins]: I think we've worked hard to get from our starting point, which I think was much more onerous based on, you know, examples that we found in other neighboring cities to try to get this to

[Collins]: a place that was a better fit for our community.

[Collins]: We've made several I think pretty major adjustments to make sure that the balance of restrictions on commercial operators and residential users was more appropriate to make sure

[Collins]: that, you know, anything that was expected of commercial operators would also be expected by municipal contractors and, you know, essentially to say we have a tool here, we have the appetite here to, we're hearing from constituents that we want this

[Collins]: source of noise pollution to be, you know, to have a lever to pull to make sure that that's at a reasonable level at reasonable times.

[Collins]: And we want to take this technology, which is known to be one of the most polluting, you know, I don't think anything, anybody expects us to solve global warming in Medford, but we, I think we've, it came from the community that we have the opportunity to take action on something that is known to be especially polluting and say, let's

[Collins]: you know, let's start to rein that in.

[Collins]: And this has been a public process to create a timeline.

[Collins]: For that we've gotten a lot of feedback on it.

[Collins]: Coming out of that we have this draft that we further amended tonight after the feedback from our new building commissioner, city staff, and legal counsel.

[Collins]: So I just wanted to thank all the constituents that have weighed in on this over the past, I think, possibly

[Collins]: It's critical for the ordinance project to get, I think that many bites at the apple and that much feedback.

[Collins]: So with that, I would motion to report this out of committee as amended.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you so much, Teresa, Roberta, for your presentation.

[Collins]: I always look forward to these meetings once or twice a year because the

[Collins]: always does such a great job of putting together, you know, not just gassing up but it's always a really great set of projects that I think, you know, we can be really proud to fund and, you know, looking at this list of the award summary for fiscal year 24 these projects are spread out all across the community like you said,

[Collins]: there's a pretty good mix between those three eligibility categories.

[Collins]: And that's always really great to see.

[Collins]: It's exciting to have a mix of projects that are in their inception and those study phases and then ones where we can see that we've been investing in these projects over years and pushing them forward to completion and being even better resources for the city to enjoy.

[Collins]: And that's just, you know, it's nice when you tee us up like that, we just get to vote on good stuff.

[Collins]: That's always great.

[Collins]: And I think it's, it's always good to have the conversation about when we're talking about investing in capital projects, investing in open space, investing in affordable housing, you know, to have that conversation about what role does the CPA funding in that because it's like you said, that's, you know, that's a that that scope can be, you know, as big as we're willing to open our eyes to see.

[Collins]: And it's good to have the conversation about

[Collins]: What role can this play?

[Collins]: Where can we put this money?

[Collins]: How far does that get us?

[Collins]: And to continue to have that conversation about contextualizing, what else would we do if the limit was higher?

[Collins]: I think this is probably one of the four council chambers that I've seen, and we pack it two or three times a year.

[Collins]: I'm going to keep it pretty short.

[Collins]: Thank you for reaching out.

[Collins]: I always appreciate residents and folks who live and work in this community for getting in touch with us directly.

[Collins]: This is how this has to work.

[Collins]: This is the dynamic.

[Collins]: We're elected.

[Collins]: You live here.

[Collins]: You work here.

[Collins]: This is our city.

[Collins]: I'm here to listen.

[Collins]: I've tried to, you know, begin that process of listening with the folks who've reached out to me over the past couple days.

[Collins]: We've heard about this over the past several days from the administration.

[Collins]: You know, I am going into this from the perspective of this decision has landed on our desks.

[Collins]: I know that the priority of folks here, the folks who work in service in the interest of public safety, I know what your priority is.

[Collins]: Your priority is the public safety of Medford residents, the people who live here.

[Collins]: As an elected representative, that has to be my priority as well.

[Collins]: I know that's the priority shared by the committee, by the community.

[Collins]: And so as we continue to listen and hear from people around this, that's going to be my guiding light is what decision will be in the best interest of executing public safety for Medford residents,

[Collins]: as well as possible every single day because of how the department is structured and any decisions that we have the jurisdiction to make around that.

[Collins]: That is going to be my lens.

[Collins]: I've said this about other policies before, you know, because it applies to many things.

[Collins]: With any decision, what I try to remember, it can't be about

[Collins]: this administration or this person in the role right now or this person who's doing the job right now, it's about the department, it's about the community, it's about today, but it's also about five years from now, 10 years from now.

[Collins]: It's always hard not to make these issues personal because we are a community made up of people who know each other and care for each other and sometimes have history with one another, but these decisions can't be made with anything other than that North Star of public safety in mind.

[Collins]: That's the perspective that I'm going into this with for the rest of the meeting.

[Collins]: I look forward to listening and hearing from people about this continuing to hear from constituents and firefighters and the administration and my fellow Councilors about this.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you so much for being here.

[Collins]: known affordable housing goals in the city, especially when we're leveraging funding that comes from outside of our community, our community.

[Collins]: It's, it's such a rare opportunity I know it's a value that shared behind this rail throughout so much of the community.
