[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I would motion to, um.

[Collins]: Adopt the condition to approve and adopt the conditions recommended by the Community Development Board and adopt the.

[Collins]: Um.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: At the most recent planning and permitting committee meeting, which is the second meeting of that committee, in keeping with the theme of preliminary meetings, we picked up a two-year-old paper to explore a home rule petition around rent stabilization and just cause eviction protections.

[Collins]: This will be the first of many conversations that we'll have on the paper with the end result being a home rule position, not an ordinance that the city council would or could pass outright.

[Collins]: So more to come on that.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: She says yes in the chat.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: The idea for this ordinance came out of conversations that I had with several members of city staff and several residents over the course of last year.

[Collins]: residents were complaining about specific sidewalks and residential neighborhoods that were rendered impassable by vegetation starting on private properties that have grown so long that folks couldn't walk on the sidewalk.

[Collins]: I've talked about this with code enforcement, and it seems like there may be a gap in our municipal code that prevents them from having the statute that they need to do enforcement when

[Collins]: the public way is impacted by plant growth, essentially, from private properties.

[Collins]: So this would just be a really targeted project to make sure that there's enabling language in our code of ordinances so that code enforcement does have the ability to issue warnings and potentially tickets if need be when folks cannot travel on the public way because of stuff coming out of private property.

[Collins]: So I would move the question to proceed this along to the Public Health and Community Safety Committee.

[Collins]: So we're talking about the housing stability notification ordinance right now.

[Collins]: This is an ordinance that we passed one year ago, actually just almost exactly a year ago, the Housing Stability Notification Ordinance.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: So it's been almost exactly a year since this council passed the housing stability notification ordinance.

[Collins]: This is a pretty specific pretty limited ordinance that says when a property owner has a tenant in a building.

[Collins]: The city shall develop a document that outlines just very, very basic tenants rights and resources, and the property owner renting to attendants to send that document to their tenant at the beginning or end of every lease.

[Collins]: It's not a document that the landlord has to create it's something that they can download off of the city website and make sure that it's conveyed to their tenant this is opposed to.

[Collins]: kind of empower people with information, and hopefully answer some questions before questions come up in the landlord tenant relationship.

[Collins]: Like I said this was passed about a year ago there's been some turnover in the planning development sustainability office this is the first time we tried to do something like this in Medford so the point of this resolution is to hold a meeting.

[Collins]: with Planning, Development and Sustainability staff and some others been working on this in the Office of Outreach and Prevention to check in on how gearing up for implementation and enforcement of this ordinance is going.

[Collins]: There are several questions to discuss, including where are we at in terms of developing that document.

[Collins]: I know that staff has been running it by legal and trying to get it to a place of completion.

[Collins]: Then there's the matter of how to make sure that

[Collins]: property owners are properly informed about this.

[Collins]: Of course, we have to make sure that we're conveying this in the communication channels to make sure that people really going to hear about it.

[Collins]: This is not intended to be punitive.

[Collins]: This is intended to be informational.

[Collins]: And I know that city staff was looking at very many communications, communication channels to make sure that the folks who need to know about this do know about this.

[Collins]: So the point of this meeting is to meet with city staff and say, how's it going?

[Collins]: Where are we at in the process?

[Collins]: How can we help?

[Collins]: So I would move to refer this conversation to the Committee on Planning and Permitting.

[Collins]: City clerk.

[Collins]: 24045 offered by as various council president resolution regarding scheduled annual budget process for FY 2025.

[Collins]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the council president request City

[Collins]: for consideration in a Committee of the Whole meeting on Wednesday, March 6, 2024.

[Collins]: Be it further resolved that, based on the schedule included in the soon-to-be finalized budget ordinance, the City Council and City Administration will follow the budget schedule for the FY 2025 City Budget.

[Collins]: By March 1, 2024, City Councilors submit individual budget recommendations for consideration by Administration and Finance Committee,

[Collins]: By Friday, March 22nd, 2024, City Council submits collective budget recommended to the mayor.

[Collins]: From April 15th, 2024 to May 15th, 2024, City Council holds preliminary budget meetings with department heads.

[Collins]: By Friday, May 31st, 2024, mayor submits comprehensive budget proposal to the City Council.

[Collins]: president bears.

[Collins]: Are there any other comments from my fellow councillors?

[Collins]: Any members of the public that would like to speak on this paper?

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Seeing no further comment on the motion of

[Collins]: President Bears as amended by Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by Councilor Tseng.

[Collins]: Six in favor, one absent.

[Collins]: The motion passed.

[Collins]: Not confirmed.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Collins]: And I thank the Councilor for chairing this meeting because I have to be remote tonight.

[Collins]: Appreciate that.

[Collins]: So this is the first time that we are talking about this paper in committee, even though it was introduced in 2022.

[Collins]: So I wanted to begin

[Collins]: with a brief overview of the paper, what it is, what it isn't, why it was brought up, when it was, and just to kind of place us at the beginning of a discussion about this topic.

[Collins]: Like I mentioned, this was brought forward by myself and President Bears in 2022.

[Collins]: At the time, this was a resolution that bundled together many ideas for housing stability-related home rule petitions.

[Collins]: It included, these ideas included rent stabilization, tenant right to purchase, tenant right to counsel, just cause eviction protections, anti-price gouging protections, exemptions for small owner-occupant landlords.

[Collins]: This was a resolution that bundled together kind of a roster of different ideas that have been used by various local municipalities all around the goal of

[Collins]: trying to introduce some stability into a housing market that is governed by market forces.

[Collins]: And I also want to speak a little bit to the particular moment during which this paper arose.

[Collins]: This was, I believe, March of 2022.

[Collins]: We had just had an issue right here in Medford Square, where a large apartment building on Bradley Road, all of the tenants had been served notices to quit.

[Collins]: The story given was renovations to the apartments.

[Collins]: But in effect, what we saw play out at the site was that a recent change of hands for the property and the property owners wanted to be able to rent those units at very much higher rates than they had been rented to for years.

[Collins]: And we saw a lot of tenants leave the community.

[Collins]: We saw a lot of tenants kind of have to react to this with not a lot of information, not a lot of options.

[Collins]: and come to the City Council for help and say, what can we do?

[Collins]: And unfortunately, we had to say, you know, there's not a lot that we can do.

[Collins]: You know, we cannot intervene in this kind of situation.

[Collins]: We can't get between, we can't get in the middle of this transaction.

[Collins]: We can provide you with folks who are experts in this type of situation, but there's nothing that the City Council can do.

[Collins]: to help you stay in your home, stay in your community, keep your commute the same, keep your kid in public schools.

[Collins]: So these ideas came out of that conversation with those tenants, I believe almost all of whom eventually ended up getting displaced out of the community.

[Collins]: And in that time, of course, we've seen other unfortunate examples of

[Collins]: rent increases so exorbitant that they had the same effect of displacing tenants out of the community when they otherwise would have remained community members.

[Collins]: So I just wanted to give that framing for why that came up when it did because it's been a little while.

[Collins]: Chair Leming, if I may.

[Collins]: Thank you so much.

[Collins]: And thank you, Councilor Scarpelli, for raising that.

[Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Collins]: I know that rent stabilization is absolutely an issue that gets people's hackles up, you know, wherever they feel about it.

[Collins]: I completely appreciate that.

[Collins]: I do want to, you know, and I think that Councilor Scarpelli, we're coming at this meeting actually in a similar frame of mind, you know, as you and I know through going through this process on various resolutions and ordinances.

[Collins]: This is the beginning of a process.

[Collins]: I think it's probably going to be a fairly lengthy and thorough process because this is such a delicate issue.

[Collins]: Let me return to sort of the framing of the issue, because I hope that I can speak to some of the concerns that you brought up, and I think that they're important ones.

[Collins]: For those folks who don't know, a home rule petition is when any city says to the state,

[Collins]: All right, state, here's a thing that ordinarily cities can't do.

[Collins]: We'd like for you to make an exception.

[Collins]: So I think that one way we can think about this process is that we're beginning the process of collaboratively drafting a piece of legislation that we would like the permission to do.

[Collins]: I know I heard from some folks this afternoon who said, please do not pass this bill.

[Collins]: We're not passing a bill tonight.

[Collins]: This is conversation number one of many about a topic that's going to take a lot of time to talk about.

[Collins]: This is just the beginning.

[Collins]: You know, there were meeting documents circulated before the meeting, which is common practice for us to circulate common drafts for Councilors to read before the meeting starts.

[Collins]: My intent, and I'll make these motions later in the meeting, is for us to open up a conversation in this meeting.

[Collins]: Afterwards, we'll circulate the documents to relevant city staff, stakeholders, and then we'll use them as a jumping off point for our next conversation on this.

[Collins]: And just to follow up on the point I was making about the Home Rule petition,

[Collins]: In the hypothetical scenario that we finish a home brawl petition about rent stabilization and just cause eviction, which is kind of the jumping off point that I created for a conversation tonight.

[Collins]: If that were to go through, if this council were to approve it, then it would go to our state delegation and the jurisdiction would be with them to approve or not.

[Collins]: And that is just the standard procedure for

[Collins]: for any Home Rule petition.

[Collins]: So I just wanted to make that clear, because I know these things are often opaque outside of City Hall in terms of the process that we're looking at here.

[Collins]: Pause there in case there are any questions from fellow Councilors on the process, or if not, I can just quickly run through more of the table setting.

[Collins]: Thank you, Chair Leming, and thank you, Councilor Sparkely.

[Collins]: I appreciate, and of course, I think it's obviously a goal that we share that everybody who'd like to weigh in has the opportunity to.

[Collins]: It's not my, as one councilor, it's not my intent that we're going to take any substantive action or vote to take actions on this draft tonight, but rather that this can be a draft that

[Collins]: constituents, councilors, stakeholders, and city staff can continue to review starting tonight and in the run-up to our next meeting on the topic, giving everybody ample time to review it, and then we'll revisit the same draft.

[Collins]: So I hope that that'll provide a lot of opportunity for people to read it and digest it before we revisit it again.

[Collins]: Having said that, and of course, happy to circle back to the process at any point.

[Collins]: I just, I think that I'm sure that there are other people in the room and on the Zoom tonight who can speak to the potential uses of rent stabilization and how it's been used in Massachusetts before later in the meeting, but just to quickly kind of frame the conversation.

[Collins]: Like I mentioned, rent stabilization, I think most people know what it is.

[Collins]: It's a way for a government entity, usually a city, to set a cap by which rent costs may not increase above that amount in a given year.

[Collins]: And then it sets forth the exceptions to that.

[Collins]: Let me find the... Trying to find a handy quote that I found in my research about this.

[Collins]: Okay, this is from, and pulling together some resources as I was preparing just myself for this meeting.

[Collins]: This is one of the strategies that the Metropolitan Area Planning Commission touches on on its website.

[Collins]: I think that they have a pretty handy encapsulation of what rent control does and doesn't do.

[Collins]: They say rent control denies unlimited excessive rent increases, thus limiting profits.

[Collins]: Rent control does, however, allow for annual increases that provide owners a fair return on investment with sufficient income to maintain property in a satisfactory manner.

[Collins]: They go on to say rent control laws usually include provisions that protect a landlord's investment in these ways.

[Collins]: For example, sometimes defining fair return, a hardship appeals process.

[Collins]: So there are

[Collins]: There are many levers and exemptions and ways to tailor these policies that I think we can look to other cities, including cities in Massachusetts, to guide our discussion as we start looking at drafts, as we get beyond the

[Collins]: preliminary table setting stage and into crafting a home rule petition.

[Collins]: I think that there's a lot of ways that cities have worked really hard to tailor this to their communities.

[Collins]: And I think that that if this project goes forward, we'll be looking to do here in Medford is to say, what does this community need?

[Collins]: And how can we tailor this to Medford?

[Collins]: Like I said, the idea for this in Medford came out of a particularly visible displacement event.

[Collins]: And that displacement in general in Medford continues to, we continue to see that happening in the community.

[Collins]: I know for myself, I'm sure for some of my other Councilors, this is something that we hear about, unfortunately, from time to time, housing scarcity.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan, for the question.

[Collins]: I circulated around noon today through the city clerk some example language from the city of Somerville, a draft jumping off point document for our discussion for a potential home rule petition here in Medford, and a link to some background info from the MAPC.

[Collins]: So you're correct, the original resolution included those ideas for seven home rule petitions.

[Collins]: I thought that, you know, seven is a lot to do in one meeting.

[Collins]: I'm not sure if it's the will of the council to advance with all of them.

[Collins]: I thought that this meeting, we could begin a conversation about rent stabilization in other communities.

[Collins]: They've bundled rent stabilization and just cause eviction together.

[Collins]: So that's what the document circulated by the clerk does.

[Collins]: Thank you, Chair Leming.

[Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Collins]: And yes, I think it would be great to start hearing from some of the other city staff and advocates that I know are in the room.

[Collins]: Just quickly, I want to say, you know, I think in my experience, it's, you know, I, sorry, two thoughts happening in my head at the same time.

[Collins]: I just want to really emphasize that for the purposes of this conversation, we are beginning a discussion about something that has been brought up by the City Council two years ago.

[Collins]: The intent to pursue this at some point has been public record for some time.

[Collins]: The content of this resolution has been public record.

[Collins]: I hear that people would like more time to look at the documents that have been circulated in support.

[Collins]: It is true that we very often get supporting documents for meetings pretty close to the meeting time.

[Collins]: At least that's been my experience for the past term.

[Collins]: And I completely respect that people want more time to look through a draft.

[Collins]: That's why I was hoping that the purpose of this meeting could be to begin the conversation and then give people the intervening two or four weeks to read it and develop feedback and bring that to our next committee meeting on this topic.

[Collins]: So I think that we're all aligned on that.

[Collins]: Before we turn it over to other speakers and people who have comments that they'd like to contribute to this discussion, I just want to again really emphasize that

[Collins]: It's true that rent stabilization is talked about as if it's one thing, and it has one set of consequences, and those are always the same, and they're always bad.

[Collins]: But that's really not true, and I think that we have the capacity and the creativity in this community to say, we have this issue.

[Collins]: We know that there are people

[Collins]: who want to move out of their parents' homes and get their own apartment in Medford.

[Collins]: We know that there are people who want to have their own place.

[Collins]: We know that there are couples that want to move in together.

[Collins]: We know that there are people who can't afford to buy a home, but love it here and want to stay.

[Collins]: And we know that rent costs are a huge problem.

[Collins]: for all of those types of people.

[Collins]: And I think that knowing this council, this is a proactive council, every member, I think that it is well worth our time to say, before we dismiss this, let's take a good long look at rent stabilization, something that other communities have looked at, and see if there's a way to tailor this to Medford so that we could keep more Medford residents in Medford.

[Collins]: And I also want to note, again,

[Collins]: And people will see this when they take more time with the examples from other communities and with the draft home repetition for Medford that are created as a jumping off point.

[Collins]: But there are myriad exemptions that we can build in to make sure that this is not anything that is going to be dramatic or drastic for people who do own rental units in Medford, exemptions for smaller types of properties, exemptions for certain types of owners.

[Collins]: That's all on the table.

[Collins]: So I hope that we can proceed with cool heads because I think that everybody's going to have something productive to continue to contribute to this conversation.

[Collins]: I'll leave it there.

[Collins]: Thank you, Chair Levening, and thank you to all of the constituents, advocates, city staff that has spoken.

[Collins]: Really appreciate getting some preliminary voices into the discussion.

[Collins]: And I think that this is

[Collins]: What our conversation just in the past 15 minutes has, I think, reinforced for me is that this is a topic and a term that is so heavily connotated that using these meetings to bring that nuance into the conversation and just to really recenter on what exactly is being proposed and how it differs from

[Collins]: the idea that we have in our heads about what rent control is or must be, I think that that'll be where we get a lot of really productive work done.

[Collins]: I appreciate raising some of the details around what we mean when we say just cause eviction.

[Collins]: And I hope that as we continue to enter into the details of this process, whether we're talking about just cause eviction or whether we're talking about really finessing the styles and levers around the specific numbers and exemptions and conditions around rent stabilization,

[Collins]: I hope that we can, I think that we'll have a really quick conversation around the nuance and how to, again, make this something that is more helpful than not.

[Collins]: And I think that grounding this in the overall context of how big of a problem displacement is in Medford and how increasing housing supply is deeply crucial and the council is very enmeshed in that work and it can never be fast enough to deal with the displacement that we have been seeing for years and continue to see.

[Collins]: And I think we just have to challenge ourselves to do more than one thing at a time.

[Collins]: So I really appreciate everybody being a part of this conversation from the outset and trying to help us do that as well as we can.

[Collins]: I would like to make a motion to recirculate the background information.

[Collins]: sample Home Rule Petition from Somerville and first draft of our Home Rule Petition from Medford that was circulated earlier today to all councillors, the Director of the Planning Development and Sustainability Office, to the Senior Planner, Housing Staff Planner,

[Collins]: Of course, these will be available on the city website under the report for this committee meeting and to request feedback and comments by February 28th.

[Collins]: And Mr. Clerk, I'd be happy to email that language over to you so you have it.

[Collins]: That's just a motion to recirculate all of the meeting documents to Councilors and staff and request feedback by the 28th.

[Collins]: I am interested in, I think my next priority would be TOPA.

[Collins]: Okay.

[Collins]: And I believe that that is included in the governing agenda.

[Collins]: I don't know that the others are.

[Collins]: I have no objection.

[Collins]: So I would motion to keep the paper in committee and motion to adjourn.

[Collins]: Thank you, Chair Tsai.

[Collins]: As for the elections commission, I think that I would just really love for the conversation that we had the last time the election commission came before us in a regular meeting.

[Collins]: In my estimation, I think the council was pretty unified in just wanting

[Collins]: a more explicit and a more specific response to the questions that we laid out in the original paper requesting the election after report.

[Collins]: And so that's, as one Councilor, that's what I'll be looking for.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: I appreciate that and I just wanted to jump in ahead of any other city staff who are going to speak and just say you know I really appreciate that overview and I think it's, it's certainly abundantly clear to me as one Councilor all the time and I feel pretty safe and speaking for my fellow Councilors that the health department, the Office of Prevention and Outreach, everybody involved in this type of preventative

[Collins]: and supportive work in City Hall, just always doing such an incredible job with the resources that they have.

[Collins]: I'm kind of always in awe of it, and I really appreciate it.

[Collins]: It's always a good time to get an overview of what is currently on offer, so I just really appreciate that.

[Collins]: You know the theme that's come up and kind of the testimony that we've heard so far that I suspect we'll hear over and over again for as long as we talk about this topic and future meetings is that, you know, just like we say that the housing crisis is a regional issue.

[Collins]: So, so too is the homelessness issue.

[Collins]: And so I think it's really

[Collins]: I think that really is at the heart of it to think about and how this plays out across a blurry line, across our various municipal boundaries.

[Collins]: But at the end of the day, we have to think about regional capacity and how we're contributing to that.

[Collins]: I'm happy to speak to any of the ordinances briefly, if helpful.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Yeah, the overgrowth ordinance was born out of conversations I've had with constituents and staff about the need to empower city staff to do enforcement around essentially when vegetation on private property is grown so long that it is obstructing the public way.

[Collins]: For example, a hedge or, you know,

[Collins]: plants in somebody's yard that are so overgrown that they're spilling into the sidewalk and people can't walk in the sidewalk.

[Collins]: They have to cross the street.

[Collins]: They have to push their stroller in the street, et cetera, just to give city staff the ability to enforce around that because currently they don't.

[Collins]: So that should be fairly straightforward.

[Collins]: That's the idea there.

[Collins]: Similarly, paper 23449 is, again, about giving city staff the authority to do enforcement around

[Collins]: you know, not around activities when they become problematic.

[Collins]: Similar to the overgrowth ordinance, it's not about policing everybody for your plants must be about a certain height.

[Collins]: It's if something is happening to such an extent that it's becoming a problem, we should be able to do something about that.

[Collins]: With the wildlife feeding ordinance, this is a measure that would empower city officials to

[Collins]: issue warnings or tickets if persistent wildlife feeding is really creating nuisances or health hazards on private property.

[Collins]: So after we run through the governing agenda I might put forward a motion to authorize myself as ordinance sponsor to circulate a draft ordinance to the members of this committee and city staff for comment ahead of this next committee meeting.

[Collins]: After that regulating the retail

[Collins]: reading facilities.

[Collins]: There is no draft for this yet, this has come out of another, this has also come out of constituent request for this regulation.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: A ordinance that we passed in 2023, the community control over surveillance.

[Collins]: over public surveillance ordinance requires the annual submission of reports from the city agencies that employ surveillance technology about those uses.

[Collins]: So this is just an annual procedure of meeting with the agency that submit those reports and discussing them, fielding questions from Councilors in the public, is something that, per the language of the ordinance, belongs with this committee.

[Collins]: So as the chair is aware, we have already scheduled the first meeting to go over an annual surveillance report for this committee's April meeting, which I am myself very much looking forward to, to go over Medford Police Department's annual surveillance report, which should only include the use of body-worn cameras for the part of the year leading up to March 2024.

[Collins]: And that process will be ongoing on an annual basis.

[Collins]: This is another sort of maintenance project that has to do with an ordinance passed in the previous term.

[Collins]: As far as my understanding goes, the implementation process for the Housing Stability Notification Ordinance, which was also passed in 2023, I believe is still being worked on by partners in the Planning Department, the Board of Health, the Office of Outreach and Prevention.

[Collins]: Getting the word out about this ordinance was, you know, no small feat to tenants and landlords alike.

[Collins]: So this project would be to follow up with those partners in how broadcasting the news of this ordinance is going, how upkeep, how uptake is going, and how we can enforce that this ordinance is known about and being followed.

[Collins]: And so this has a goal start date of April.

[Collins]: I know our April meeting date, as we just said, is already pretty full.

[Collins]: So maybe the chair and I can work on scheduling an appropriate date to schedule a meeting to begin to take up this project as well.

[Collins]: Yes, it's my understanding and again, this, of course, the, uh, the parameters of this project would be.

[Collins]: put forward by the Councilor that's leading on it, and it's currently listed as no Councilor owning this project.

[Collins]: It's just put forward as a good idea.

[Collins]: So I don't want to speak for whoever leads on this project and their priorities, but it's my understanding that rather than fitting, rather than creating a maintenance plan for emergency equipment based on a particular year's operating schedule, this is more about reconciling our emergency fleet

[Collins]: with our capital spending plan, which is a multi-year document.

[Collins]: So I think that this wouldn't need to wait for the submission of any annual operating budget, but rather be something that we do in parallel with our long-term budget planning collaboration with the administration.

[Collins]: Just for clarity.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you for the question.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I appreciate my fellow Councilors for bringing this forward.

[Collins]: I certainly will be comfortable supporting the resolution tonight.

[Collins]: I think it's also fine to discuss it more with relevant stakeholders and community members.

[Collins]: For me, putting aside the medical and therapeutic uses associated with psychedelic plants, it's certainly not my belief that drug-related arrests and prosecutions should be a law enforcement priority, except when it comes to

[Collins]: some of the things specifically exempted in the resolution, such as unauthorized commercial sale, distribution of minors, driving under the influence.

[Collins]: Recent history, I mean, not so recent history has shown us that criminalization of substances does not meaningfully advance public health and public safety.

[Collins]: At the same time, this is a holistic issue, so I look forward to future discussion about it.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I've put forward an amended version of the resolution.

[Collins]: I would motion to amend the resolution and adopt the revised language.

[Collins]: A copy is in front of, sorry, a copy of the amended resolution is in front of all councilors and in the hands of the clerk.

[Collins]: I would motion to amend the resolution and adopt the new language and have it read into the record.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you for reading all of that into the record.

[Collins]: I want to briefly speak to why I'm putting forth an amended resolution from what was submitted to be incorporated in the Council's formal agenda.

[Collins]: After I put forward the resolution last week, I was contacted by many constituents who urged me to reconsider the language before us.

[Collins]: With an issue such as this, it is critical to speak with as much clarity and precision as possible, even when and especially when it's uncomfortable.

[Collins]: I was called upon to amend this resolution to more authentically and faithfully represent the harms endured on both sides of the Israel and Palestinian border.

[Collins]: In addition, while the ultimate ask of this resolution is for an immediate and enduring bilateral ceasefire, I was also called upon to not let the historical context go unsaid and unacknowledged.

[Collins]: I thank everybody who got in touch with me from the original request to put forward a ceasefire resolution to the many people who gave me feedback and worked with me to improve it.

[Collins]: Despite my note about updating the language of this resolution, I also want to put forth a disclaimer that I don't believe I personally have the ability or maybe it's simply not possible to talk about this issue in a way that does not leave one group or another at risk of feeling diminished or blamed or impoverished.

[Collins]: If you are feeling that way, please blame me or blame the insufficiency of language to talk about an issue that is breaking all of our hearts and has been breaking all of our hearts for decades, and most especially many people in this room.

[Collins]: And thank you for being here.

[Collins]: I want to speak briefly to why I elected to bring this resolution forward, apart from the fact that I was contacted by constituents to do so, that being the ultimate reason.

[Collins]: I am Jewish.

[Collins]: My ancestors on both sides came to America in the early 1900s because Eastern Europe wasn't safe for them.

[Collins]: My last name is Collins because my great-grandfather couldn't get a job with a Jewish last name.

[Collins]: My family knows that anti-Semitism is real and it is dangerous.

[Collins]: I believe that past hardship and trauma and persecution are never valid nor meaningful, but we can seek to make past trauma and hardship, we can seek to get something out of that if we put that experience in service of other people and stand in solidarity with other people who are also facing oppression and persecution.

[Collins]: Now we see a right-wing government using the grief of Jewish people, like me, and the name of Jewish people to justify the destruction of an entire civilian population in Gaza.

[Collins]: There are no words that can adequately capture this horror, pain, and injustice.

[Collins]: This resolution is long, but the ask is simple.

[Collins]: Our US government is deeply entwined with and invested in the Israeli military.

[Collins]: Our federal leaders have the influence, the power, and the purse strings to hasten an end to the killing.

[Collins]: This issue is painful and divisive, more for some than for others.

[Collins]: But ultimately, this resolution is about safety, and I believe that should unify us.

[Collins]: Marginalizing Palestinians, whether legally, physically, or in the media, advances no one's safety.

[Collins]: It's simply not right, and I would defy anyone to tell me that the mass murder, displacement, and destruction in Gaza will leave Israeli residents more safe from violent extremism.

[Collins]: Some people would question the validity of city-level resolutions about this issue.

[Collins]: To me, this is a Medford issue because Medford residents are invested in the issue.

[Collins]: And while the U.S.

[Collins]: government condones the killing and sends unrestricted military aid to Israel, communities right here in the U.S.

[Collins]: are starved for funding.

[Collins]: If you attend any average city council meeting, what you'll hear us talk about ultimately is how there aren't enough public dollars to pay for resident services, fully funded schools, affordable housing, road safety, and on and on.

[Collins]: Meanwhile, our federal leaders authorized billions to help bomb kids in Gaza.

[Collins]: I find that

[Collins]: I find it unfathomable on a human level, and I find it infuriating as a Councilor.

[Collins]: Those dollars should be promoting wellness at home, not destruction abroad.

[Collins]: I hope that we can find unity in the unacceptability of this oppression and this loss of life, and in demanding an immediate and lasting de-escalation and ceasefire in Gaza.

[Collins]: I hope that we as a council can join the groundswell of city councils, amplifying their residents' calls for ceasefire, and add Medford's voice to the chorus for peace.

[Collins]: I hope we can find unity in diminishing no one's suffering and trauma, and in demanding safety and peace for all.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you to everybody who spoke.

[Collins]: I already made the motion to adopt the new language and move forward with that new language.

[Collins]: Motion to adopt, yeah, that's what I said.

[Collins]: And I'll now motion to amend and adopt the new language.

[Collins]: Got it.

[Collins]: I hear everybody.

[Collins]: I hear all of you.

[Collins]: I don't know if it's possible for everybody to be heard equally, but I hear you.

[Collins]: And I motion for approval of the resolution as amended.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I appreciate Councilor Lazzaro for bringing this forward.

[Collins]: I'm really excited to start a discussion of what we can do to pilot a warming and cooling center of our own here in Medford.

[Collins]: As Councilor Lazzaro stated, we've known for a long time now that it's not sustainable to keep directing our unhoused neighbors to the resources in other communities to stay safe and warm at night.

[Collins]: communities and other resources are already overburdened.

[Collins]: We need to start sometime at figuring out a path towards strengthening our own safety net and supportive services here in Medford.

[Collins]: Obviously, this is really complicated and expensive, but it's important, and we all know that Medford has the creativity and the collaboration and the spirit of service to get it done.

[Collins]: Motion to take paper 24028 out of order.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Thanks.

[Collins]: I got it.

[Collins]: Um, can you hear me?

[Collins]: 24028 offered by President Bayer's resolution calling on U.S.

[Collins]: government to end blockade of Cuba.

[Collins]: Whereas for 60 years, the United States has imposed an embargo on Cuba, having a devastating economic, social, and political impact on the people of Cuba.

[Collins]: And whereas U.S.

[Collins]: Senators Warren and Markey, U.S.

[Collins]: Representatives McGovern, Presley, Lynch, Moulton, and Tran,

[Collins]: city councils in neighborhood cities, and many state and local officials have called on the Biden administration to restore the policies of the Obama administration, reducing travel restrictions and removing Cuba from the state sponsors of terrorism list that were reversed under the Trump administration.

[Collins]: And whereas the continuation of this policy has a detrimental impact on Medford residents and organizations who have family, business and research ties with people and organizations in Cuba.

[Collins]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford city council that we urge the Biden administration

[Collins]: and our congressional delegation to reverse the Trump decision to add Cuba to the state sponsors of terrorism list and restrict travel between the two countries and be it further resolved by the Medford City Council that we urge our congressional delegation to pass legislation to repeal any laws regarding the embargo on Cuba and be it further resolved that the city clerk please submit this resolution to the offices of Senator Warren, Senator Markey and Representative Clark.

[Collins]: This is a huge project.

[Collins]: This will probably organize most of the other projects within this committee over the course of the next 23 months.

[Collins]: President Bears and I have initiated, I mean, this project has been initiated at the very end of last term.

[Collins]: The council selected a zoning consultant to work with this council to structure this process to provide

[Collins]: you know, specialized expertise in implementing.

[Collins]: the comprehensive plan, the housing production plan, the climate adaptation plan, other known goals and shared values that this community has, that the administration has, that this council has, and make sure that those are borne out in a comprehensive review and updating of the zoning process.

[Collins]: And just to clarify, do you think what would be valuable is sort of like goals or maybe like last action taken?

[Collins]: This is why this is here right now.

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Just making a note of that.

[Collins]: And I think we can definitely, as we start to spin up our process of sort of end of month updating of the governing agenda, we can certainly workshop that and figure out a way to just quickly

[Collins]: make sure that that like one or two sentences for each project is being revised.

[Collins]: So this, the structuring, the breaking down this very large two-year project into manageable pieces is something that this committee will be working on in concert with NS Associates, which is the zoning consultant that this council selected, and Planning Development and Sustainability staff.

[Collins]: But the overall approach, I think, will be to take

[Collins]: our ambitious goals of reviewing and updating all of our zoning ordinances, find a way to organize that by goal, by topic, by category, so that we can be doing those updates, be making those updates in a way that makes sense and is efficient.

[Collins]: There's certainly a lot for us to get through in two years.

[Collins]: So what that organization, what that structure looks like is something that we will be meeting about and talking about in coming weeks and months.

[Collins]: President Bears.

[Collins]: Yeah, I really appreciate that kind of approach to how to work through this.

[Collins]: I think that I think that some version of that approach is what we will inevitably end up doing.

[Collins]: I think that one way we might come to that approach is we are working with planning development

[Collins]: kind of have a two track approach to breaking this down into manageable pieces.

[Collins]: I think that our zoning consultant might have a perspective on what categories

[Collins]: might make sense to work on together.

[Collins]: And then of course, from this council being representatives of the community and being very well versed in these plans, we then, I think it is, in my opinion, as one councilor, I think it's our role to then come to those topics with a set of priorities and say, this is our priority for what we do in the realm of doing something that affects housing stock, housing density, housing character.

[Collins]: based on what we know from our plans, based on what we know from constituents.

[Collins]: I think that individual Councilors getting very specific on what we would like to do in certain categories, something that we could certainly start to do at any time, and I think that when we are able to sync up with NS associates and planning staff in the next few weeks about what kind of timeline we might be looking at as we work to develop that timeline of what we'll work on when, that might give us some clarity on

[Collins]: when could we collectively have those conversations about what's going on our punch list and figure out a process from there.

[Collins]: But I agree.

[Collins]: I think that I suspect that we all have in our heads those specifics that we're shooting for.

[Collins]: And quite soon will come the time, sooner than we know it, will come the time to start implementing those.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Collins]: I think that's a really important point with anything, and especially with a project of this scale that we've been gearing up to for such a long time.

[Collins]: I think it'll be really important.

[Collins]: Well, to me, I'm thinking a lot about budgeting time for this project, because it's such a big, ambitious project.

[Collins]: And I think that avoiding duplicating efforts will be really crucial.

[Collins]: And it dovetails with what Councilor Callaghan was saying about how and when are we getting organized to make sure that we're doing what we want to do.

[Collins]: Just to run quickly down the list of ordinances that are also in this committee, the Condo Conversion Ordinance, this is one that I'm leading on.

[Collins]: We started work on this last year.

[Collins]: The goal of this is to create some conditions and permitting procedures around when rental units are taken off the market by for-profit developers and turned into condos to make sure that the community recaptures some of that value that is just being realized as real estate value.

[Collins]: The status on that is there was a bunch of takeaways and great research questions from our last meeting, which was sometime last fall, that I have to follow up with the building commissioner about.

[Collins]: And I hope that we can get about that quite soon and get it passed by May.

[Collins]: many people in Medford.

[Collins]: Like we've talked about, some of our projects are

[Collins]: serving as liaison to bring together people who could work on implementing a program that's outside of our legal jurisdiction, but it's something that we have the platform to do.

[Collins]: There are other cases where it is an ordinance that is something that we have the power to promulgate.

[Collins]: If we're thinking about how to tailor this in a way that enforcement is going to go most successfully because we can do the legislation we don't do the enforcement.

[Collins]: I found it valuable to involve those city staff and other partners who'd be involved in enforcement and implementation early in the process so that what we are

[Collins]: creating can be that balance between in line with our values and our aspiration, and achievable and actionable and doable.

[Collins]: So I think the short answer is, there's no right answer.

[Collins]: I appreciate the, the question around this just, and I think that's.

[Collins]: You know, the best encapsulation in terms of.

[Collins]: You know, for the newer Councilors in the room in terms of.

[Collins]: the ways that this frequently comes to us.

[Collins]: Certainly, we all have some level of understanding of the problem in its totality and why we're here and for how long it's been going on and the big pieces of why the problem is so widespread, which is our incredibly high percentage of private ways and very old infrastructure and a lot of rehabilitation and renovation that needs to be done and is incredibly expensive that we can't currently right now pay for, capital improvements.

[Collins]: In my experience, how this comes up to the council on a week-by-week, month-by-month basis is residents continue to raise the issue, as is their right, and it's important for us to be a forum for them to come to with questions, whether it's, this keeps happening, who can I talk to?

[Collins]: Or this keeps happening and I live on a private way, and we very frequently have to be the bearer of bad news because it is incredibly financially burdensome to people who live on private ways to do

[Collins]: ideal renovations in many of those cases and it is also financially infeasible for the city at this point to just assume all of those private ways because they have to be brought to code first and that's millions and millions of dollars.

[Collins]: So in my experience, when constituents come to this body and they say, hey, me and my neighbors have been having this problem, it's an opportunity to have a conversation.

[Collins]: And we've had that conversation at least many times in the one term that I've served so far.

[Collins]: And it's a way to convey that information.

[Collins]: And I think it's a way to continue to resurface the kind of the bottom line issues that

[Collins]: partners in City Hall and the PPW engineering are already working on that is, you know, unfortunately, but necessarily long term projects and deeply involved with the capital future of the city.

[Collins]: as a cohort, we are discussing and keeping updated with what's where, how things are progressing, if timelines or goals need to be adjusted, that we're making those decisions as a group twice yearly.

[Collins]: For example, I would love to see

[Collins]: or maybe talk about in subcommittee, if that's a more reasonable timeline for this, what is our policy for when old elections materials are destroyed or removed from the office so that we know they will never be put in a ballot for which they're irrelevant, that kind of procedure.

[Collins]: You know, similarly, I know one of the issues that I was hearing the most about on election day was the interfacing of wardens and voters at the polls around things like voter guides or how people were checked in.

[Collins]: Totally heard that most of the wardens did a fine job, you know, did the role that they were hired to perform.

[Collins]: You know, this is one of the areas of the city where we really have to strive for perfection because voting rights are inalienable and we have to

[Collins]: It's just essential that everybody has the full accessibility to their vote and everything that comes along with that.

[Collins]: So this is why this has been a project for us to deliberate on this and meet on this and want to go over this to make sure that we're all entering into a resilient election year together.

[Collins]: And I think that the interfacing between the poll workers and those going to the polls, that is an issue where we have to, again, we have to strive for perfection every single time because it's a voter enfranchisement issue.

[Collins]: It's a confidence issue.

[Collins]: I know on the issue of staffing, that's one that we brought up when we raised this paper to begin with.

[Collins]: And among our questions and directives, it's not just for this report.

[Collins]: And again, I really thank you for the detail you've put into this.

[Collins]: We also had a motion to the administration to say, clearly there's a staffing need.

[Collins]: There's a demonstrated, there's an articulated staffing need.

[Collins]: We wanna know how we can help expedite that.

[Collins]: I think this council is pretty young.

[Collins]: The previous council was unified in saying,

[Collins]: the election department needs staff, let's get it staffed up.

[Collins]: But if we need to dial down on that to get specific on

[Collins]: here's exactly what we need in the next budget cycle for a fully staffed elections department.

[Collins]: Let's have those conversations.

[Collins]: If we need to get specific about here's how many wardens and poll workers that we had for the November, 2023 election.

[Collins]: And it was a little thin and we know that turnout is going to be different.

[Collins]: So here's what we need to shoot for.

[Collins]: And let's talk about and communicate and make public the plan for getting to that number as close as we can to it.

[Collins]: I think that these are conversations that would really behoove us to go over publicly, you know, for our edification and again for that project of reestablishing some of the confidence that has been lost.

[Collins]: And ideally, hopefully to, you know, add to the efforts of advertising the poll worker positions.

[Collins]: I appreciate Councilor Scarpelli's motion to continue this conversation in a subcommittee of the government's committee.

[Collins]: I think that that will really help us to flesh out some of the additional detail and specific next steps that we'd like to see beyond this report.

[Collins]: And again, I thank you for your time and for all your hard work all year round.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: I want to again thank you for the level of depth in this conversation tonight.

[Collins]: your goings-on, you know, talking about successes as well as the problems that, you know, I know that we have a shared goal of shoring up every year.

[Collins]: And I'm glad to end this conversation or put a pin in it for now, you know, on the issue of resources and capacity.

[Collins]: Appreciate the discussion around this.

[Collins]: either the third or the fourth time that we've discussed this in these chambers.

[Collins]: My alternative proposal went even further.

[Collins]: It would have achieved pay parity between the school committee and the city council by 2027.

[Collins]: First person to do the right thing.

[Collins]: I believe that there's no space for passivity in that role.

[Collins]: And that's why I believe that our role should be paid equally.

[Collins]: In any case, I think, you know,

[Collins]: to the headlines of this issue.

[Collins]: It's been 24 years since there's been a pay adjustment for the school committee.

[Collins]: This is a one-time adjustment spread out over two years, and then it stops.

[Collins]: We've already referred to the governance committee, apart from the

[Collins]: motion that will vote on from Councilor Callahan, the recommendation to study within the concept of our, sorry, within the review of our city charter, which we'll be doing later this year, a mechanism for triggering some sort of automatic or regular evaluation of all elected salaries.

[Collins]: And I think that's important.

[Collins]: not so that the salaries necessarily go up, but I think that part of the issue here has been, since there was not any sort of regular mechanism other than the city council deigning to consider an increase, we've gone 24 years without considering it.

[Collins]: And that's why the initial proposal was for a triple-digit percentage increase, because we had so much time to make up for.

[Collins]: So with all that being said, I'm glad that we're going to have that conversation later this year so that we can continue having this conversation about how to align compensation with our goals and our values and how to promote the elected bodies that our community deserves.

[Collins]: And I'm looking forward to voting on compensation increase, one that I believe is fair and reasonable and very certainly the product of compromise tonight.

[Collins]: So thank you very much.

[Collins]: I think that we need to challenge ourselves to do more than one right thing at a time.

[Collins]: But as

[Collins]: folks who are familiar with our work and the parameters of our jurisdiction know, when it comes to the budget and its appropriations, we get to vote yes or no, and that is it.

[Collins]: We cannot appropriate.

[Collins]: And so this does put us in this awkward position where we can instigate these compensation adjustments, and we can't do that directly for anybody else.

[Collins]: And I think for that,

[Collins]: that we do in these chambers the entire rest of the year.

[Collins]: This is a really unusual topic for us to be talking about the entire rest of the year.

[Collins]: I think we can be we can challenge ourselves to be the allies that the community deserves by supporting all other city employees and bargaining units by one vocally supporting them and standing with them and advocating for them and also by doing the bulk of the work of this council, which is doing the ordinances and the zoning and the business development work.

[Collins]: in this chambers in collaboration with the administration, in collaboration with private partners that will bring up the city's bottom line and enable us to, as swiftly as we can, roll out improved living wages for all city employees, because that is all of our goals.

[Collins]: I do not believe that this stands in the way of that goal, and that goal is not diminished by this change.

[Collins]: And that's my opinion.

[Collins]: We are a legislative body.

[Collins]: We make policy.

[Collins]: School committee is a legislative body.

[Collins]: They make policy.

[Collins]: Thank you for your deference, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Collins]: So we have two proposals before us.

[Collins]: school committee compensation and that of all elected officials in a regularized way.

[Collins]: Maybe it's an automatic COLA increase, but I think one of the things that has made this conversation very difficult is that talking about school committee pay at all is an entirely discretionary conversation for the city council to bring up.

[Collins]: And so it's been 23 years since we have, since I think it's been very murky, who controls that and why and how does it get brought up?

[Collins]: And I think that that's just been a disservice to the conversation.

[Collins]: All that to say, I don't know which of, if either of the two proposals that have currently been proposed will go forward.

[Collins]: I'd like to propose a third towards that goal of setting some sort of creating some kind of mechanism for us to revisit this more than once every 23 years when everybody thinks of it.

[Collins]: The motion would be for this council to refer this paper to the governance committee for consideration during charter review with the goal of creating a mechanism within the updated city charter to trigger automatic COLA increases and or compensation review for all elected positions at regular interviews.

[Collins]: And I can forward that language to you, Mr. Clerk, if you like.

[Collins]: And just to reiterate, the goal here is to come out of this with some sort of mechanism for looking at elected compensation so that it doesn't fall by the wayside for 23 years, because I think that that is one of the ingredients in this scenario when we haven't talked about it in a couple decades.

[Collins]: And so when we do, one of the things we contemplate is a triple digit percentage increase because it's just been so long since we talked about it.

[Collins]: Thank you, that's my motion.

[Collins]: the bottom line budget that affects how much we can appropriate to the schools for the schools to then appropriate.

[Collins]: Once it enters the schools, we don't touch it, except for this.

[Collins]: That is all part and parcel of this work, and it is, in terms of dollars, more impactful.

[Collins]: 24007, offered by President Bears.

[Collins]: Resolution to amend rule 33 of the rules of Medford City Council to establish standing committees.

[Collins]: be it resolved by the Medford City Council that rule 33 committees of the rules of the Medford City Council be amended to the following.

[Collins]: After the organization of the council, the president of the council shall form and set standing meeting times for the committee of the whole and the following standing committees.

[Collins]: Administration and Finance Committee, Education and Culture Committee, Governance Committee, Planning and Permitting Committee, Public Health and Community Safety Committee,

[Collins]: Public Works and Facilities Committee, Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee.

[Collins]: All councilors shall be considered as members of each standing committee.

[Collins]: The president shall name those members of each committee, including its chair and vice chair, who are authorized to vote on matters in the committee.

[Collins]: All other members of each committee are not authorized to vote on such matters in the committee.

[Collins]: A quorum of the committee shall be determined on the basis of voting members only.

[Collins]: Each committee chairperson shall form subcommittees and appoint members of subcommittees as needed.

[Collins]: The president or committee chairperson will give way to committee and subcommittee appointments via the longevity and interest of such appointees.

[Collins]: Resolutions, ordinances and other papers are referred to committee by a majority vote of the members at a regular meeting of the City Council.

[Collins]: If a councillor requests, the committee chair shall place any paper referred to the committee on the next scheduled committee meeting agenda or the agenda for another scheduled committee meeting.

[Collins]: be it further resolved that papers and committee be referred from 2022 through 2023 subcommittees to 2024-2025 committees as described in the attached memorandum describing the proposed updated council committee structure.

[Collins]: 24009 offered by President Bears's resolution to request Board of Health implement winter eviction moratorium.

[Collins]: Whereas many cities and countries prohibited evictions between November 1 and March 31 due to winter cold that puts lives in danger and whereas Massachusetts has yet to implement a statewide policy to protect families from becoming unhoused

[Collins]: and put out on the street in dangerously cold weather, and whereas over 1,200 households were evicted in Massachusetts in the winter of 2022 through 2023.

[Collins]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we request that the Board of Health declare an annual state of emergency and implement an eviction moratorium each winter to protect the health and safety of residents who face potentially fatal illness if evicted during the winter.

[Collins]: President Bears.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Collins]: We'll go to Councilor Tseng and then Councilor Callahan.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Collins]: on the motion to table by President Bears, seconded by Councilor Tseng.

[Collins]: Any further discussion?

[Collins]: We're at the 23-412, which is already under unfinished business.

[Collins]: We're just motioning to table that, but not to a specific date.

[Collins]: All in favor?

[Collins]: All opposed?

[Collins]: Motion passes.

[Collins]: It stays on the table.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Collins]: the good landlord tax credit.

[Collins]: This is kind of the colloquial phrase for a local option that was included very recently in the state tax relief package under Governor Healey.

[Collins]: Essentially, this provides now a new way for cities to give a property tax break to landlords who choose to keep their rents below market rate.

[Collins]: So it is a way to, in different framings, either incentivize or reward or

[Collins]: thank, if you want to put it that way, small landlords who opt to offer more affordable rents to their tenants.

[Collins]: It's not a one-size-fits-all mechanism.

[Collins]: Cities can have several levers that they can pull on.

[Collins]: They can choose

[Collins]: up to what percentage of property tax to exempt landlords from.

[Collins]: They can choose whether to enact this option for landlords who, oh, I always get this wording messed up.

[Collins]: You can enact this if rents are affordable up to 200% AMI.

[Collins]: We have the option to narrow it so that it's just for landlords who provide only much deeper affordability.

[Collins]: That's like a whole spectrum that this council could investigate and decide what might be the best fit for this community, and all communities have that option.

[Collins]: So there's a lot to deliberate on to explore this option further and decide what might be the best fit for Medford, for our landlords that are offering low market rate rents, all towards the goal of incentivizing small landlords to do this, because we have such an acute and ever-worsening affordable housing scarcity and crisis in Medford, as we do throughout the region, and as a way to make making that choice to offer affordability

[Collins]: a little more doable for landlords and to further incentivize them to do so.

[Collins]: And so my motion is to send this to the administration and finance committee where we can have a start discussion about it with our chief assessor and our finance director about implications for the city and get their insight on how to implement this.

[Collins]: Sorry, now that we have approved the resolution to adopt committees with titles, I should just amend this to refer to the Administration and Finance Committee and not committee.

[Collins]: The updates align our current ordinance with best practices promulgated by MassDEP.

[Collins]: We worked closely with the Planning Development Sustainability Office and the DPW Commissioner to make sure that this would align with what we are looking to do to hold the waste haulers in our community more accountable to our goals for having this be a smooth and efficient process for residents and businesses, as well as getting us closer to our waste reduction goals.

[Collins]: The students, their families, the teachers, the paras.

[Collins]: all of the workers in our schools that help students and students' families thrive.

[Collins]: I do not believe that this proposal is incompatible with that shared goal whatsoever.

[Collins]: the equity between the school committee and the city council is something that I've wanted to, that I've hoped to have the opportunity to vote on ever since I first took office.

[Collins]: These are two elected bodies.

[Collins]: I know how hard we work.

[Collins]: I have some glimmer of perspective of how hard the school committee works.

[Collins]: They have responsibilities that we don't.

[Collins]: I think it is outdated that our bodies are paid differently.

[Collins]: That is the core reason for my support for this proposal.

[Collins]: And even if it were to stop right there, that would be enough for me.

[Collins]: But I see that this draws in a larger conversation about what we can and can't do in Medford, what we have and haven't done in Medford so far, especially every June during budget cycle and really all year round.

[Collins]: If you watch the city council meetings, if you watch the school committee meetings, we are constantly talking about the resources that are afforded to Medford public schools, the people that work in them and everybody that experiences the work that is done in those buildings.

[Collins]: And we are constantly in this conversation about why aren't we doing better and how can we continue to do better

[Collins]: to better value and better resource what goes on in the schools, and better value and better resource the people that do the work of the schools.

[Collins]: This proposal, I think, has brought up those values and those feelings and that imperative that we have to keep doing better.

[Collins]: What I don't believe is that this is an either-or, and what I don't believe is that this is a zero-sum game.

[Collins]: I know that if this proposal were to go forward even as written before amendments,

[Collins]: This is not, this would not take from the same bucket of money that would otherwise go to the workers that contribute to MPS students experience.

[Collins]: Hang on, please.

[Collins]: Thank you, thank you for letting me speak.

[Collins]: This year, we found out that we had a 25 million sum of certified free cash, $25 million.

[Collins]: When we talk about what we can and can't do in Medford and what we have and haven't done, I think that we need to stay, I try to stay, laser focused on what our real opponent is.

[Collins]: Our real opponent is austerity budgeting.

[Collins]: I believe that we have the money to value the people who choose to nominate themselves for school committee and go through the process of running and seek election and serve in that role.

[Collins]: that we have the resources, that we can marshal the resources to do better by everybody who contributes to the Medford public school system.

[Collins]: We talk about it all year long.

[Collins]: We talk about how little authority the school committee, sorry, we talk about where the city council's authority lies and doesn't lie when it comes to making direct appropriations to our budgets, including the school budgets.

[Collins]: We talk about this.

[Collins]: all the time, often in great frustration.

[Collins]: We don't have the power to influence bargaining units here in the city council.

[Collins]: We don't have the authority to make appropriations whatsoever that is out of our purview.

[Collins]: I know, speaking for myself, there's been countless times when I wished it was in our purview, because I'm so frustrated by what I see in the line items in the budgets that we have to vote yes or no on, because that's all that we can do on those budgets.

[Collins]: So when it comes back to this proposal,

[Collins]: Due to the constraints of our jurisdiction here, this is something that we are legally allowed to vote on.

[Collins]: And there are many things that we will never have the opportunity to vote on, because that is not within our purview.

[Collins]: When something comes in front of me that is an opportunity to discuss and interrogate, is this an opportunity to do a good thing?

[Collins]: I want to take that opportunity.

[Collins]: And I do not think it is in any way incompatible with continuing to do better.

[Collins]: in the many areas, the many school-related areas where we need to keep doing better.

[Collins]: It's not a zero-sum, and it's not an either-or.

[Collins]: I look forward to hearing the discussion tonight, and I look forward to continuing to hold ourselves accountable to do this right, and to do right by all of our public employees, and to do as many things right as we can, all at the same time.

[Collins]: And I don't think that we have to choose between one or the other.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: And they're not a choice that we make in this branch of government.

[Collins]: I hope that a silver lining of this conversation can be elucidating for this body and for the school committee and for the residents, how our budgets get made.

[Collins]: It's an ongoing process of making the budget every year.

[Collins]: And for us, it just means approving it.

[Collins]: We cannot appropriate, we cannot weigh in on collective bargaining.

[Collins]: We cannot move money from one salary to another.

[Collins]: We're sorely limited in what we can do.

[Collins]: And I hope that this ongoing process allows us to have the conversation with the community

[Collins]: how our budgets are shaped, and who shapes them, and what limited power lies where, because I think it's beneficial for the community to get a better sense of how that pie gets baked.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Roehl.

[Collins]: So this is a project that we've been working on in subcommittee since March.

[Collins]: The real seeds of this project were in the Solid Waste Task Force that met for a lot of 2022 under the direction of

[Collins]: Director Hahn and consultants towards the goal of looking at tools available to us to start our next waste hauling contract with best possible deal for the city both in terms of cost effectiveness and in terms of progressing towards our zero waste goals which of course is integral to our overarching sustainability goals and one of the things that came out of that conversation not just recommendations for

[Collins]: our next waste hauling contract was actually to tweak the existing Medford legislation around solid waste in Medford to make sure that we had the legislative foundation to make sure that we could hold our future waste hauler vendor to account in accordance with our sustainability goals.

[Collins]: So in the Subcommittee on Ordinances and Rules, we worked closely with Director Hunt and her department.

[Collins]: There are a couple

[Collins]: main changes that we made, but overall we just took our existing waste hauling ordinance, which was pretty outdated in a lot of ways.

[Collins]: So we made sure that it was updated to align with best practices coming out of the MAS DEP.

[Collins]: And the origins of this document start with their template language.

[Collins]: So it's been thoroughly vetted.

[Collins]: This aligns with what other communities do in terms of waste hauling.

[Collins]: One of the most consequential changes is that there's now a bundled service requirement, which essentially just says, if you offer trash pickup in Medford, you have to also offer recycling.

[Collins]: And this is significant, because that way, vendors that only offer trash pickup cannot undercut vendors that offer both on price.

[Collins]: And this will allow us to recycle the most in Medford in the most cost-effective way, which affects people on the city contract as well as everybody else.

[Collins]: That's the main strokes.

[Collins]: We did work with Director O'Connor from the Board of Health to make sure that this document aligns with current Board of Health regulations for waste haulers because they do, they operate the permitting side to make sure that everything is consistent to make this legible and understandable for generators as well as vendors.

[Collins]: I do have a few last amendments that I'll make from the floor just on the definitions in article one after any further comment or questions from my fellow Councilors.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Amendments?

[Collins]: Great.

[Collins]: And thank you so much for your comments, and to everybody who worked on this with me.

[Collins]: So just quickly, just some quick amendments for Article 1 in general.

[Collins]: This was the last piece that we didn't amend in subcommittee, but I have some amendments that were run past a whole host of department heads, and I have a list if people are interested in seeing.

[Collins]: We just wanted to take section 71, 72, sorry, 70-1, 70-2, and 70-3, put those into contemporary language and

[Collins]: make sure that everybody who ought to be, every department that ought to be mentioned in those sections so that they could be tasked with enforcement would be.

[Collins]: So I can read off those amendments.

[Collins]: They're just a short paragraph each, and I'll also email that language to the city clerk.

[Collins]: Yes, I'll email it to you.

[Collins]: have the draft queued up but I didn't send it unless there was any controversy about this.

[Collins]: Who will speak for the cinders?

[Collins]: Well, I don't know who speaks for the cows.

[Collins]: So for Section 70-1, the motion would be to strike the existing and replace with, you should have this in your email inbox,

[Collins]: No private property may become a gathering place for debris, refuse, discarded, or abandoned items or other waste.

[Collins]: Any property owner who has received written notice from the Department of Public Works, Medford Police Department, Code Enforcement Officer, or Medford Board of Health to remove any such material from their property must do so within the timeframe directed.

[Collins]: Second is to take the existing section 70-2 and strike that and replace it with no debris, refuse, discarded items, or other waste, including yard waste and construction debris may be placed or dumped in any public place or public way in the city.

[Collins]: All waste must be properly contained and properly placed for collection on scheduled collection days in accordance with the regulations, schedules, and policies promulgated by the Department of Public Works and Board of Health.

[Collins]: Any person who has been ordered by the Department of Public Works, Medford Police Department, code enforcement officer, Medford Board of Health, or designee thereof

[Collins]: to remove any improperly discarded material or waste from private or public property must do so within the time frame directed.

[Collins]: And then finally, to just strike 70-3 because that information has been subsumed into the proposed 70-1 and 70-2.

[Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Collins]: Present.

[Collins]: Thank you, President Merlin.

[Collins]: well, comprehensive projects that we've hired them for.

[Collins]: It's hard to say no to that kind of springboard.

[Collins]: They've already put their arms around the community as a whole through the comprehensive plan and other projects with your department.

[Collins]: I think that

[Collins]: That strikes me as very encouraging.

[Collins]: I see that they've worked comprehensively with the communities, I see that they've worked with the communities on kind of more targeted specific projects, whether it's kind of a gateway cities approach, a creative district, the MBTA Communities Act, and they also have the comprehensive experience with the communities as well.

[Collins]: And that seems like a really good fit to me, because I think that our voting overhaul will require

[Collins]: both that bird's eye view approach and also the, you know, I think we have areas of the city where we want to take a really specific lens and say we're trying to do this here in accordance with part of what's, some of the goals that's been laid out through our various plans.

[Collins]: You know, looking through Fisher's portfolio projects, it's really compelling as well.

[Collins]: I know that they have deep experience in their region that they've done a lot of work in.

[Collins]: The Innis proposal shows a real depth of experience in communities that share some characteristics to ours around Massachusetts, and I find that especially compelling.

[Collins]: Thank you.

[Collins]: Present.

[Collins]: Not a question, but I just wanted to thank you, pardon me, again for speaking to us about this topic.

[Collins]: I know it, I think it speaks to the need for, you know, I know it's an ever-evolving project too, because protocols around private ways have been shifting for such a long time and there's been kind of a systemic lack of clarity.

[Collins]: It's not totally surprising that this comes up every six months or 12 months.

[Collins]: I think it's good that we're talking about

[Collins]: options for getting the word out to more residents within our capacity, like a mailing or, I mean, even just, I agree, even a really simple webpage, I think, would help folks in our position who, you know, kind of have to dole out information about private ways to residents when it comes up multiple times a year to try to, you know, over the long term, get more people on the same page throughout the city.

[Collins]: So it's great to have a conversation about that.

[Collins]: I know that we're going to try to move the needle on that as we can.

[Collins]: and I think it's to everybody's benefit, you know, to just be reminded of what we're working against here and the responsibilities that we have that govern that public funds overall and how unfortunately incredibly expensive it is to do what we really want to do, which is to, you know, have that full jurisdiction over all of the roads that all residents live on.

[Collins]: I think it's just helpful to get sobering as it may be, you know, and reminders of what a big task that is for the city to do comprehensively and what we need to do in interim steps to try to improve resident enjoyment and, you know, equal enjoyment of residential roads in the meantime as we try to keep our eye on the prize for what will it take to, you know, fully adopt private ways over the long term and what are the reasons for doing that and what can people do in the meantime.

[Collins]: I appreciate this conversation and for me it's helpful for communicating that to residents and I hope that it's helpful in our ongoing efforts to let residents know.

[Collins]: I have a motion to receive and place on file and adjourn.

[Collins]: Thank you, really appreciate the work of the planning staff that went into this.
